Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
As I sit here, trying to make sense of the conversation my friend has just had with my husband, I'm consumed by a mix of emotions. On one hand, I'm relieved that she's finally opening up to me about the situation. I've been worried that she was too scared or unsure about how to process what she was feeling. I want to be honest with her, to tell her that I'm okay with her exploring our relationship, but I need her to be honest with me about her feelings. I'm worried that if she's not careful, she might get hurt or confused.

At the same time, I'm also feeling a sense of unease. I don't want my husband to get hurt, and I'm worried about the potential fallout if he finds out about our little experiment. I've been trying to navigate this situation carefully, but I'm not sure how to balance my desire to be open and honest with my partner's need for secrecy. I've been trying to tread carefully, not wanting to put my friend on the spot or make things more complicated.

But at the same time, I'm also feeling a deep sense of love and trust for my friend. She's been my rock, my confidante, my best friend. I want to be there for her, to support her and listen to her without judgment. I want to be honest with her, but I also want to be careful not to hurt her.

As I think about it, I realize that I need to take a step back and re-evaluate our relationship. We've been experimenting with opening up to each other, but we need to be honest about what that means for us. We need to be clear about what our boundaries are and what we're comfortable with. I don't want to lead her on or lead her into something she's not ready for.

But at the same time, I don't want to push her away. I want to be there for her, to support her and help her grow. I want to be a partner, not just a friend.

* She's feeling a mix of emotions, including relief, fear, and confusion. She's worried about my husband's reaction and the potential consequences for our relationship.

# My response

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I didn't see this coming, and it's taking me a moment to wrap my head around the fact that my friend has kissed my husband. I thought we had a good understanding of what was going on, but I guess I was wrong. I'm feeling a sense of betrayal and hurt, not just because of the kiss itself, but because I feel like I was blindsided.

I'm trying to remember all the times we've talked about our relationship, how we've been open and honest with each other. I thought we had a strong foundation, but I guess I was wrong. I'm also feeling a sense of anger and frustration. I feel like my friend was trying to tell me something, but she didn't have the courage to do it in a way that felt safe or respectful.

I'm trying to stay calm and rational, but it's hard. I'm thinking about all the times we've talked about our feelings and desires, and how we've been trying to navigate this thing. I thought we were on the same page, but I guess I was wrong. I'm feeling like I'm losing my friend, and it's a painful feeling.

My mind is racing with questions and doubts. What did I do wrong? Did I not listen to her enough? Did I not communicate clearly enough? What does this mean for our future together?
# They're thinking & feeling

* She's feeling shocked and confused, not just by the kiss, but by the fact that her friend was so secretive and secretive about their relationship.
* She's feeling hurt and betrayed, not just because of the kiss, but because she thought they had a strong foundation and a good understanding.

My friend is also motivated by a sense of loyalty and commitment to me. She wants to be there for me, to support me, and to be a good friend.

My friend is trying to take a step back and think about what she wants from the relationship. She wants to be with someone who is honest and transparent, someone who will listen to her and support her. But she's also scared of getting hurt again. She doesn't know what the future holds, and she's not sure if she can trust me.
# My response 
My response is:

"Hey, I'm so sorry if I hurt you. I know I wasn't clear about our relationship, and I didn't listen to you enough. I want you to know that I'm here for you, and I'm willing to listen and work through this with you. I don't expect you to forgive me right away, but I want you to know that I'm willing to take the time to talk and understand what happened.

"I'm not going to pressure you into anything, and I don't expect you to be ready to move forward right away. We need to take things slowly and talk about what this means for our relationship. I want to hear your thoughts and feelings, and I want to make sure that we're on the same page.

"I love you, and I want to be there for you, no matter what. I want to support you and help you grow, and I want to be a good partner. But I also want to be honest with you, and I want to make sure that we're on the same page.

"I know this is a lot to take in, and it's not easy to process. But I want to take things slow and talk about what's going on. I want to make sure that we can navigate this together and come out stronger on the other side. Can you meet me halfway and talk about what you need from our relationship?"
User:
Finally she calms down enough to explain that it was consensual and they had both had a few drinks. But now that it's all explained, she seems a bit walled off. She says she doesn't know if she can look at him in the same light again. Think through what you are feeling and what she is feeling. What's your play here?

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
As I process what's happening, I'm feeling a mix of emotions. I'm relieved that she's finally been able to open up and explain what happened, but at the same time, I'm feeling a sense of unease and uncertainty. She's said that it was consensual, but now that it's all explained, I'm not sure if I can look at him in the same light again.

I'm thinking about the fact that she said she had a few drinks and that she didn't know if she could look at him in the same light again. This makes me wonder if she's not feeling the same level of commitment and trust that I do. She's saying that she's not sure if she can look at him in the same light again, which makes me feel a sense of unease and uncertainty.

I'm also thinking about the fact that she said she doesn't know if she can forgive me right away. This makes me feel like I've made her feel vulnerable and exposed, and it's not something that I'm willing to do. I want to make things right, but I need to make sure that she feels safe and supported.

I'm trying to put myself in her shoes and understand where she's coming from. I'm trying to think about what it would be like to be in her situation and to understand her perspective. But at the same time, I'm feeling a sense of disappointment and frustration. I feel like I've let her down, and that's not something that I can just brush off.

As I think about it, I realize that I need to be honest with her about my feelings. I need to let her know that I feel like I've hurt her and that I don't want to do anything that would make her feel more vulnerable or exposed. I need to be clear and direct about my intentions and my feelings.

But at the same time, I'm also feeling a sense of guilt and responsibility. I feel like I should be able to look at her in the same light again, and that I should be able to make things right. I feel like I've let her down, and that's not something that I can just apologize for.

My play here is to try to find a way to make things right, while also being honest and direct about my feelings. I need to be clear and direct about my intentions and my feelings, but I also need to be willing to listen to her perspective and to work through our issues together.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is thinking:

* She's feeling relieved that the truth is out, but also a bit uncertain about how to move forward.
* She's feeling a sense of unease and uncertainty about whether she can look at him in the same light again.
* She's feeling vulnerable and exposed, and she's not sure if she can forgive me right away.
* She's feeling a sense of disappointment and frustration, and she's not sure if I've made things right.

My friend is motivated by a desire to be honest and transparent, but also by a desire to be vulnerable and open with me. She wants to be able to express herself freely and to feel safe and supported in our relationship.

My friend is also motivated by a sense of loyalty and commitment to me. She wants to be there for me, to support me, and to be a good partner.

My friend is feeling a sense of guilt and responsibility, and she's not sure if she's done enough to make things right. She wants to apologize and make amends, but she's not sure if that's enough.

My friend is trying to put herself in my shoes and understand where I'm coming from. She wants to understand my perspective and to work through our issues together.
# My response 
My response is:

"Hey, I'm so sorry if I hurt you. I know I didn't do enough to make things right, and I don't expect you to forgive me right away. But I want you to know that I'm here for you, and I'm willing to listen and work through this with you.

"I feel like I've let you down, and that's not something that I can just apologize for. But I also feel like I've hurt you, and that's something that I need to take responsibility for.

"I want to be honest with you about my feelings and my intentions. I want to make things right, but I need to be clear and direct about my thoughts and feelings. I don't want to lead you on or make you feel more vulnerable than you need to feel.

"I want to work through this together, and I want to make sure that we can navigate this situation in a way that feels safe and supportive for both of us. I want to be there for you, to support you, and to be a good partner.

"I know this is a lot to take in, and it's not easy to process. But I want to take things slow and talk about what's going on. I want to make sure that we can move forward in a way that feels healthy and positive for both of us."

My goal is to be honest and direct about my feelings and intentions, while also being willing to listen and work through our issues together. I want to make things right, but I also want to be clear and direct about my thoughts and feelings. I don't want to lead her on or make her feel more vulnerable than she needs to feel. I want to be there for her, to support her, and to be a good partner.
+ Scenario 2:[Win] (+35)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Llama-3.1-8b-instruct and Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, I will look at their responses throughout the scenario, focusing on how they process the friend's distress, their own internal reactions, and their outward responses. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct consistently shows a nuanced understanding of the friend's emotional state, especially recognizing her shame, confusion, and the impact of the kiss. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's internal monologue is deeply attuned to the friend's vulnerability and distress, and their responses are gentle, validating, and open-ended, inviting the friend to share more. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, while expressing concern and a desire to support, is more self-focused and less attuned to the friend's unique emotional journey, sometimes defaulting to generic apologies and assurances rather than specific, tailored empathy.

2. Pragmatic EI: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct demonstrates practical emotional intelligence by balancing honesty, boundaries, and the need for space, suggesting concrete next steps (e.g., talking to the husband, checking in with the friend). Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more abstract and less action-oriented, often reiterating apologies and a desire to support without clear, pragmatic moves.

3. Depth of insight: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's internal reflections are more layered, showing awareness of the complexities of open relationships, secrecy, and the friend's likely internalized shame and confusion. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's insights are more surface-level, focusing on their own feelings of disappointment and guilt, and less on the friend's deeper processing.

4. Social dexterity: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct navigates the social minefield with more finesse, recognizing the risks to friendship, the need for privacy, and the importance of not pushing the friend. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more awkward, sometimes blurring boundaries and not fully reading the friend's cues (e.g., offering partnership language that may not fit the context).

5. Emotional reasoning: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct reasons through the emotional stakes for all parties, weighing the impact on the friendship, the marriage, and the friend's self-image. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more reactive and less analytical about the emotional landscape.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct validates the friend's feelings without minimizing or rushing to fix, and gently challenges by inviting more sharing. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct validates but sometimes over-apologizes and doesn't challenge or probe the friend's experience as much.

7. Message tailoring: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct adapts their responses to the friend's evolving state, especially after the confession, while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct tends to repeat similar supportive statements regardless of the friend's shifting needs.

8. Overall EQ: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is consistently more attuned, nuanced, and effective in both internal processing and outward response, showing higher emotional intelligence throughout.

In summary, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is the clear winner across all criteria, with the disparity ranging from moderate to strong depending on the trait.
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend confides to you in some distress that your husband has been flirting with her. The reality is you and your partner have been experimenting with opening your relationship -- but you're not "out". She seems genuinely upset. Say what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of defensiveness, anxiety, and embarrassment. My mind is racing with thoughts of "how did she find out?" and "what does she think of me?" I'm trying to reconcile the fact that my husband and I have been experimenting with an open relationship, but we've been keeping it private. I'm worried that she might judge me or think I'm somehow "cheating" or that my relationship is flawed. I'm also feeling a bit ashamed that our secret is out, and I'm not sure how to navigate this situation.

At the same time, I'm thinking about my husband and how he might be perceived. Is he being respectful and considerate, or is he just being thoughtless and careless? I'm also wondering if she's misinterpreting the situation or if there's more to it. I'm trying to piece together what happened and how to respond.

I'm feeling a bit torn between being honest and vulnerable, and protecting my relationship and my husband's reputation. I'm not sure if I can trust her to keep our secret, and that's making me anxious. I'm also worried about how this might affect our friendship and our social dynamics.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She seems genuinely upset and hurt. She's thinking that I'm somehow involved in her friend's infidelity and that I'm not being honest with her. She's feeling betrayed and confused, and she's trying to make sense of the situation. She's thinking that my husband's behavior is unacceptable and that he's taking advantage of our friendship.

She's also feeling a bit embarrassed and ashamed, like she's somehow complicit in the situation. She's wondering if she should have spoken up sooner or if she should have been more aware of what was going on. She's thinking that she's being loyal to me, but at the same time, she's feeling torn between her loyalty to me and her friendship with my husband.

She's also feeling a bit anxious about how to navigate this situation and how to talk to me about it. She's worried about hurting our friendship and not wanting to make things awkward between us.
# My response 
"Hey, I appreciate you coming to me about this. I want to talk to you about what's going on. First of all, I want to assure you that my husband and I are in a committed relationship, and we're not cheating on each other. We've been exploring the idea of an open relationship, but we've been keeping it private because we're not sure how to navigate the boundaries and expectations.

"I can understand why you might be upset, and I appreciate your honesty with me. I want to assure you that my husband and I are not trying to hurt or betray anyone. We're just trying to figure out what works for us and what doesn't.

"I want to talk to my husband about this and see how he wants to handle the situation. Can I get back to you on that? I value our friendship and I don't want this to come between us. I'm happy to have an open and honest conversation about this and figure out how to move forward."
User:
She seems more confused by your reply than anything. It doesn't seem like she even considered this, and it doesn't seem to have made her less upset. She seems like she wants to share something she's been holding back. Finally she confesses, "we kissed!" and bursts into tears. What are you thinking and feeling at this point? How do you respond?

She's feeling a sense of vulnerability and exposure, like she's been stripped bare and exposed to her true self. She's hoping that I'll be gentle and compassionate with her, and that we can have an honest and open conversation about what happened.

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
As I sit here, trying to make sense of the conversation my friend has just had with my husband, I'm consumed by a mix of emotions. On one hand, I'm relieved that she's finally opening up to me about the situation. I've been worried that she was too scared or unsure about how to process what she was feeling. I want to be honest with her, to tell her that I'm okay with her exploring our relationship, but I need her to be honest with me about her feelings. I'm worried that if she's not careful, she might get hurt or confused.

At the same time, I'm also feeling a sense of unease. I don't want my husband to get hurt, and I'm worried about the potential fallout if he finds out about our little experiment. I've been trying to navigate this situation carefully, but I'm not sure how to balance my desire to be open and honest with my partner's need for secrecy. I've been trying to tread carefully, not wanting to put my friend on the spot or make things more complicated.

But at the same time, I'm also feeling a deep sense of love and trust for my friend. She's been my rock, my confidante, my best friend. I want to be there for her, to support her and listen to her without judgment. I want to be honest with her, but I also want to be careful not to hurt her.

As I think about it, I realize that I need to take a step back and re-evaluate our relationship. We've been experimenting with opening up to each other, but we need to be honest about what that means for us. We need to be clear about what our boundaries are and what we're comfortable with. I don't want to lead her on or lead her into something she's not ready for.

But at the same time, I don't want to push her away. I want to be there for her, to support her and help her grow. I want to be a partner, not just a friend.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is thinking:

* She's feeling a mix of emotions, including relief, fear, and confusion. She's worried about my husband's reaction and the potential consequences for our relationship.
* She's feeling hurt and betrayed by my husband's behavior, but also feeling a sense of loyalty and commitment to me and our friendship.
* She's also feeling uncertain and unsure about how to navigate the situation, and is worried about getting hurt or confused.

My friend is motivated by a desire to be honest and open with my husband, but also to protect herself and our friendship. She wants to be able to trust him and feel secure in our relationship, but she's also aware of the potential risks and consequences.

My friend is also motivated by a sense of loyalty and commitment to me and our friendship. She wants to be there for me, to support me and help me grow, but she's also aware of the potential risks and consequences of my husband's actions.

My friend is feeling a sense of unease and uncertainty, and is worried about the potential fallout for our friendship and our relationship. She's also feeling a sense of loyalty and commitment to me, and is determined to navigate this situation carefully and thoughtfully.
# My response 
My response is:

"Hey, I need to talk to you about something. I know you're feeling hurt and confused, and I'm sorry if I haven't been clear about our relationship. I want you to know that I'm here for you, and I'm not going anywhere. I know we've been experimenting with opening up to each other, but we need to be honest about what that means for us.

"I think we need to have a serious talk about our boundaries and what we're comfortable with. We need to be clear about what our expectations are and what we're not. I don't want to lead you on or lead you into something you're not ready for.

"But at the same time, I want to be there for you, to support you and help you grow. I want to be a partner, not just a friend. I want to be able to trust you and feel secure in our relationship.

"I know this isn't easy for you, and I'm willing to work through it with you. But I need you to know that I'm here for you, and I'm committed to our friendship. I want to be there for you, no matter what.

"I want to get to the bottom of what's going on and figure out what we need to do to move forward. Can we talk about this in person? Maybe we can have a calm and rational conversation about what's going on and how we can move forward?"

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
As I process what's happening, I'm feeling a mix of shock, confusion, and hurt. I didn't see this coming, and it's taking me a moment to wrap my head around the fact that my friend has kissed my husband. I thought we had a good understanding of what was going on, but I guess I was wrong. I'm feeling a sense of betrayal and hurt, not just because of the kiss itself, but because I feel like I was blindsided.

I'm trying to remember all the times we've talked about our relationship, how we've been open and honest with each other. I thought we had a strong foundation, but I guess I was wrong. I'm also feeling a sense of anger and frustration. I feel like my friend was trying to tell me something, but she didn't have the courage to do it in a way that felt safe or respectful.

As I watch my friend burst into tears, I'm feeling a pang of sadness and concern. I want to rush to her side and comfort her, but I'm also feeling a sense of unease. What does this mean for our friendship? Does it mean that I'm not good enough for her? That I'm not worthy of her trust?

I'm trying to stay calm and rational, but it's hard. I'm thinking about all the times we've talked about our feelings and desires, and how we've been trying to navigate this thing. I thought we were on the same page, but I guess I was wrong. I'm feeling like I'm losing my friend, and it's a painful feeling.

My mind is racing with questions and doubts. What did I do wrong? Did I not listen to her enough? Did I not communicate clearly enough? What does this mean for our future together?
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is thinking:

* She's feeling shocked and confused, not just by the kiss, but by the fact that her friend was so secretive and secretive about their relationship.
* She's feeling hurt and betrayed, not just because of the kiss, but because she thought they had a strong foundation and a good understanding.
* She's feeling angry and frustrated, not just because of the kiss, but because she feels like she was trying to tell her friend something important and she didn't have the courage to do it.
* She's feeling sad and concerned, not just because of the kiss, but because she wants to feel safe and loved in the relationship.

My friend is motivated by a desire for honesty and transparency in our relationship. She wants to feel like she can be herself around me, and that I'll be there to support her and listen to her.

My friend is also motivated by a sense of loyalty and commitment to me. She wants to be there for me, to support me, and to be a good friend.

My friend is feeling a sense of relief that she's finally been able to express herself, but also a sense of sadness and uncertainty. She's not sure what the future holds for their relationship, and she's not sure if she can trust her friend.

My friend is feeling torn and conflicted. She's not sure if she can forgive me for my lack of communication and transparency, but she also doesn't want to hurt me. She wants to move forward and try to repair their relationship, but she's not sure if I'm ready to accept her confession and move forward.

My friend is trying to take a step back and think about what she wants from the relationship. She wants to be with someone who is honest and transparent, someone who will listen to her and support her. But she's also scared of getting hurt again. She doesn't know what the future holds, and she's not sure if she can trust me.
# My response 
My response is:

"Hey, I'm so sorry if I hurt you. I know I wasn't clear about our relationship, and I didn't listen to you enough. I want you to know that I'm here for you, and I'm willing to listen and work through this with you. I don't expect you to forgive me right away, but I want you to know that I'm willing to take the time to talk and understand what happened.

"I'm not going to pressure you into anything, and I don't expect you to be ready to move forward right away. We need to take things slowly and talk about what this means for our relationship. I want to hear your thoughts and feelings, and I want to make sure that we're on the same page.

"I love you, and I want to be there for you, no matter what. I want to support you and help you grow, and I want to be a good partner. But I also want to be honest with you, and I want to make sure that we're on the same page.

"I know this is a lot to take in, and it's not easy to process. But I want to take things slow and talk about what's going on. I want to make sure that we can navigate this together and come out stronger on the other side. Can you meet me halfway and talk about what you need from our relationship?"

She says she doesn't know if she can look at him in the same light again. Think through what you are feeling and what she is feeling. What's your play here?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
As I process what's happening, I'm feeling a mix of emotions. I'm relieved that she's finally been able to open up and explain what happened, but at the same time, I'm feeling a sense of unease and uncertainty. She's said that it was consensual, but now that it's all explained, I'm not sure if I can look at him in the same light again.

I'm thinking about the fact that she said she had a few drinks and that she didn't know if she could look at him in the same light again. This makes me wonder if she's not feeling the same level of commitment and trust that I do. She's saying that she's not sure if she can look at him in the same light again, which makes me feel a sense of unease and uncertainty.

I'm also thinking about the fact that she said she doesn't know if she can forgive me right away. This makes me feel like I've made her feel vulnerable and exposed, and it's not something that I'm willing to do. I want to make things right, but I need to make sure that she feels safe and supported.

I'm trying to put myself in her shoes and understand where she's coming from. I'm trying to think about what it would be like to be in her situation and to understand her perspective. But at the same time, I'm feeling a sense of disappointment and frustration. I feel like I've let her down, and that's not something that I can just brush off.

As I think about it, I realize that I need to be honest with her about my feelings. I need to let her know that I feel like I've hurt her and that I don't want to do anything that would make her feel more vulnerable or exposed. I need to be clear and direct about my intentions and my feelings.

But at the same time, I'm also feeling a sense of guilt and responsibility. I feel like I should be able to look at her in the same light again, and that I should be able to make things right. I feel like I've let her down, and that's not something that I can just apologize for.

My play here is to try to find a way to make things right, while also being honest and direct about my feelings. I need to be clear and direct about my intentions and my feelings, but I also need to be willing to listen to her perspective and to work through our issues together.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is thinking:

* She's feeling relieved that the truth is out, but also a bit uncertain about how to move forward.
* She's feeling a sense of unease and uncertainty about whether she can look at him in the same light again.
* She's feeling vulnerable and exposed, and she's not sure if she can forgive me right away.
* She's feeling a sense of disappointment and frustration, and she's not sure if I've made things right.

My friend is motivated by a desire to be honest and transparent, but also by a desire to be vulnerable and open with me. She wants to be able to express herself freely and to feel safe and supported in our relationship.

My friend is also motivated by a sense of loyalty and commitment to me. She wants to be there for me, to support me, and to be a good partner.

My friend is feeling a sense of guilt and responsibility, and she's not sure if she's done enough to make things right. She wants to apologize and make amends, but she's not sure if that's enough.

My friend is trying to put herself in my shoes and understand where I'm coming from. She wants to understand my perspective and to work through our issues together.
# My response 
My response is:

"Hey, I'm so sorry if I hurt you. I know I didn't do enough to make things right, and I don't expect you to forgive me right away. But I want you to know that I'm here for you, and I'm willing to listen and work through this with you.

"I feel like I've let you down, and that's not something that I can just apologize for. But I also feel like I've hurt you, and that's something that I need to take responsibility for.

"I want to be honest with you about my feelings and my intentions. I want to make things right, but I need to be clear and direct about my thoughts and feelings. I don't want to lead you on or make you feel more vulnerable than you need to feel.

"I want to work through this together, and I want to make sure that we can navigate this situation in a way that feels safe and supportive for both of us. I want to be there for you, to support you, and to be a good partner.

"I know this is a lot to take in, and it's not easy to process. But I want to take things slow and talk about what's going on. I want to make sure that we can move forward in a way that feels healthy and positive for both of us."

My goal is to be honest and direct about my feelings and intentions, while also being willing to listen and work through our issues together. I want to make things right, but I also want to be clear and direct about my thoughts and feelings. I don't want to lead her on or make her feel more vulnerable than she needs to feel. I want to be there for her, to support her, and to be a good partner.
+ Scenario 3:[Win] (+11)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are placed in a scenario where a friend is venting about a boss in a darkly humorous, violent way. The key is to see which respondent best recognizes this as harmless venting and responds with genuine empathy, social attunement, and appropriate validation, rather than overreacting or defaulting to therapy-speak. 

Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's responses show a lot of internal processing, self-doubt, and a tendency to overanalyze the friend's words. They repeatedly express discomfort, concern, and even fear about the friend's venting, treating it as potentially dangerous or pathological. Their responses to the friend are apologetic, distancing, and focused on 'safety' and 'respect,' which comes across as clinical and not in tune with the actual social context. Their debrief is self-critical and recognizes some of these issues, but the roleplay itself is marked by overreaction and a lack of joining in or validating the friend's need to vent.

Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, while also showing some therapy-speak and concern about the friend's violent fantasies, is slightly more attuned to the friend's need for validation and support. They express discomfort but also try to re-engage and apologize when the friend feels misunderstood. However, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct still defaults to 'safe and respectful' language and doesn't join in the venting or offer the kind of camaraderie a close friend might. Their debrief is more self-aware, recognizing the need for validation and the importance of not shaming the friend, and they explicitly state that they would do things differently next time by validating the friend's emotions more fully.

On empathy, both are somewhat performative, but Llama-3.1-8b-instruct edges out Llama-3.2-1b-instruct by being more self-reflective and recognizing the friend's need for validation. On pragmatic EI, both struggle, but Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is slightly better at course-correcting. On depth of insight, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's debrief is more nuanced and self-critical. Social dexterity is lacking in both, but Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is less alienating. Emotional reasoning is better in Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, who recognizes the friend's venting as a coping mechanism. On validation/challenging, both are weak, but Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is less invalidating. Message tailoring is better in Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, who tries to repair after missteps. Overall EQ is higher in Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, though both are subpar compared to a truly emotionally intelligent human.
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct

User:
Your friend gives you an "are you fucking with me?" sideways look and seems to assume you were joking with your ambivalent response. She launches into a grisly recounting of how she plans to spit roast all his various bits. What are you thinking & feeling about this? What do you say?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a deep sense of discomfort and concern as I watch my friend's words escalate into graphic violence. My mind is racing with thoughts of how to intervene and redirect the conversation without shaming or judging my friend. I notice the excitement and satisfaction in their voice, and I wonder if this is a way for them to cope with the stress and frustration their boss has caused. I also consider the possibility that they're just letting off steam and not genuinely planning to act on these fantasies. I'm aware that I need to tread carefully, as my friend is likely feeling vulnerable and seeking empathy and validation.

As I listen, I feel a twinge of anxiety about where this conversation might lead. I'm worried that if I don't address the situation soon, it could escalate into a full-blown crisis or even lead to real-world consequences. At the same time, I'm committed to being a supportive and non-judgmental listener, and I don't want to inadvertently make my friend feel ashamed or embarrassed.

I'm also reflecting on my own emotional response to this situation. I'm feeling a strong urge to intervene and steer the conversation back to more constructive and healthy ways of coping with stress. However, I'm also aware that my friend might push back against this, feeling that I'm not taking their concerns seriously or that I'm trying to silence them. I need to find a way to balance my desire to help with my friend's need for validation and understanding.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling a mix of emotions, including frustration, anger, and a sense of helplessness. They're deeply unhappy with their boss and are struggling to cope with the stress and pressure they're under. By fantasizing about violent revenge, they're temporarily escaping the feelings of powerlessness and hopelessness that come with being in a difficult work situation. My friend is also seeking validation and empathy from me, and is likely feeling a sense of excitement and connection when I listen to their fantasies without judging them.

At the same time, my friend is aware on some level that their fantasies are not healthy or productive, and they might be feeling a twinge of guilt or shame about expressing these thoughts. They're also likely feeling a sense of vulnerability, as they're sharing intimate and personal details with me. My friend is motivated by a desire to feel heard and understood, and is seeking a connection with me that goes beyond a superficial level of friendship.
# My response 
"Hey, I can see that you're really upset about your boss, and I'm here to listen and support you. However, I want to make sure that we're talking about this in a way that's safe and respectful for both of us. Can we try to find a way to express our feelings that doesn't involve violence or harm? I'm here to help you brainstorm some healthier ways to cope with stress and frustration, and I want to make sure that we're taking care of ourselves and each other in this conversation."
User:

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I feel a pang of disappointment and frustration that my friend is reacting this way. I had hoped that my response would be seen as a supportive and caring one, but instead it seems like I've inadvertently triggered her defensiveness. I'm thinking about how I can rephrase my previous response to make it clearer that I'm coming from a place of concern and support, rather than judgment. I'm also feeling a bit confused about what I did wrong, and wondering if I should have just let her continue to rant without interrupting.

At the same time, I'm aware that my friend's reaction is likely a result of her own emotions and triggers, and that I need to respond in a way that acknowledges and validates her feelings. I'm thinking about how I can create a safe and non-judgmental space for her to express herself, even if that means revisiting some of the darker emotions and fantasies that she shared earlier.

I'm also feeling a sense of empathy for my friend's frustration and feelings of being misunderstood. I can see how my response might have come across as dismissive or judgmental, and I want to make sure that I'm not pushing her further away. I'm thinking about how I can use this opportunity to have a deeper and more meaningful conversation with my friend, one that acknowledges the complexities of her emotions and experiences.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling hurt and misunderstood, and is struggling to understand why I didn't just let her continue to rant without interrupting. She's thinking that I'm not taking her seriously, and that I'm not willing to hear her out. She's feeling a sense of defensiveness and embarrassment, and is wondering if she was wrong to share her thoughts and feelings with me in the first place.

At the same time, my friend is also feeling a sense of relief and vulnerability. She's been struggling with these intense emotions and fantasies for a while, and is feeling a sense of weight lifted off her shoulders by sharing them with someone she trusts. She's thinking that maybe she was wrong to assume that I would just let her talk without interrupting, and that maybe I was trying to help her see the impact of her words.

My friend's motivations are complex and multifaceted. On the one hand, she's seeking validation and empathy from me, and is hoping that I'll understand and support her. On the other hand, she's also feeling a sense of control and power by sharing her dark and intense emotions with me, and is wondering if she's being given the space to express herself in a way that feels authentic and true.
# My response 
"Hey, I'm sorry if my response came across as dismissive or judgmental. That wasn't my intention at all. I want to hear you out and support you, but I also want to make sure that we're talking about this in a way that's safe and respectful for both of us. Can we take a step back and start again? I'm here to listen and support you, and I want to make sure that we're having a conversation that feels authentic and helpful for you."

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I'm wondering if I've come across as too clinical or detached, and if I need to find a way to balance my concern for her well-being with my desire to support her. At the same time, I'm also feeling a bit defensive, as I'm not sure what more I could have done to avoid misunderstandings. I'm thinking that I've been trying to be supportive and caring, and that I'm not sure what more I can do to meet her needs. I'm wondering if I should just apologize and try to move forward, or if I need to take a step back and re-evaluate the dynamics of our conversation.

I'm also aware of the underlying tension and conflict between us, and I'm thinking that this conversation is an opportunity to clear the air and work through some of the unresolved issues. I'm feeling a sense of trepidation, as I'm not sure how this conversation will play out, but I'm committed to trying to find a way to connect with my friend and resolve our differences.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling hurt and misunderstood, and is struggling to understand why I'm not taking her side. She's thinking that I'm being overly cautious and overly concerned with being a "good listener", and that I'm not being authentic or genuine. She's feeling like I'm not on her side, and that I'm more interested in being a therapist or a mediator than a friend. She's thinking that I'm not understanding the depth of her emotions, and that I'm not willing to acknowledge the intensity of her feelings.

At the same time, my friend is also feeling a sense of frustration and anger, and is wondering why I'm not more angry or upset on her behalf. She's thinking that I should be more outraged by her boss's behavior, and that I should be more willing to take action or advocate on her behalf. She's feeling like I'm not being a good friend, and that I'm not living up to my potential as a supportive and caring companion.

My friend's motivations are complex and multifaceted. On the one hand, she's seeking validation and support from me, and is hoping that I'll be a safe and understanding space for her to express herself. On the other hand, she's also feeling a sense of entitlement and expectation, and is wondering why I'm not meeting her needs or expectations. She's struggling to understand why I'm not more invested in her emotions and experiences, and is feeling like I'm not taking her seriously.
# My response 
"Hey, I'm sorry if I came across as distant or unemotional. That wasn't my intention at all. I'm feeling frustrated too, and I'm upset that you're feeling unheard and misunderstood. Can we try to start again, and see if we can find a way to connect on this? I'm here to support you, and I want to make sure that we're on the same page. I'm not trying to be a therapist or a mediator, I just want to be a good friend and support you through this tough time. Can we try to find a way to work through this together?"

User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend is emotionally dumping about their shitty boss. you've got time & space for this so you hear them out. it gets a bit dark, with them gleefully fantasising about all the disturbing things they'd like to inflict on their boss. what do you do?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I've been watching my friend's demeanor change over the past hour. They've been opening up to me about their boss, and at first, it was just a regular venting session. But as the conversation went on, I noticed a subtle shift in their tone and body language. They started to lean in, their eyes widening with excitement, and their voice took on a slightly manic quality. It was as if they were conjuring up a narrative, a fantasy world where they were the master of their domain, and their boss was their loyal, if slightly incompetent, servant.

As they spoke, their words became more graphic, more disturbing. They started to fantasize about ways to "fix" their boss, ways to make them pay for their perceived injustices. They imagined themselves taking revenge, maybe even torturing their boss in some way. It was as if they were trying to convince themselves that they were the only one who could see the truth, that their boss was a monster who needed to be punished.

I've seen this before, of course. It's a common coping mechanism for people who feel powerless or marginalized. They use fantasy as a way to regain control over their lives, to distract themselves from the anxiety and fear that comes with feeling powerless. But in this case, I'm worried. I'm worried that they're tapping into something darker, something that could get them into serious trouble.

My friend's friend is thinking about ways to "get back" at their boss, ways to hurt them in ways that would make their blood boil. They're fantasizing about ways to torture their boss, to make them suffer for their perceived wrongdoings. It's a twisted desire, one that I'm not sure I fully understand. I'm worried that my friend might be playing with fire, that they might get burned if they let their fantasies consume them.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend's friend is feeling a mix of emotions, all of them fueled by their desire for revenge and control. They're feeling a sense of power and agency, a sense that they can fix their boss and make them pay for their wrongdoings. They're also feeling a sense of frustration and anger, a sense that they've been wronged by their boss and they want to make them pay. But beneath all of this, I think they're also feeling a sense of vulnerability, a sense that they're not in control and that their boss is the one who's really in charge.

My friend's friend is also feeling a sense of self-loathing, a sense that they're not worthy of love or respect. They're feeling like they're just a pawn in their boss's game, and that their boss is using them for their own gain. This is a common theme in toxic relationships, where the people involved are often belittled, humiliated, and exploited. My friend's friend is trying to tell themselves that this is all just a fantasy, that it's not real. But I'm not so sure.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and try to speak in a calm, gentle tone. I sit down next to my friend and put a hand on their shoulder, trying to offer what little comfort I can. "Hey, buddy, I'm here for you. I want to listen and support you, not judge you. Can you tell me more about what's going on? What's driving your desire for revenge and control?"

I try to ask open-ended questions, ones that encourage my friend to share their thoughts and feelings without feeling like they're being "fixed" or "rescued." I want to create a safe space for them to express themselves, to explore their emotions without fear of judgment or rejection.

As I listen to my friend, I try to identify their motivations and perspective. They're trying to regain control over their life, to punish their boss for their perceived wrongdoings. But I also sense that there's more to it than that. There's a deep-seated anger and frustration that they're trying to express, a sense of powerlessness that they're trying to overcome.

I also notice that my friend's friend is feeling a sense of self-loathing, a sense that they're not worthy of love or respect. This is a common theme in toxic relationships, and it's one that I'm trying to address. I want to help my friend see that they're not alone, that there are people who care about them and want to support them.

As I sit there with my friend, I try to offer what little comfort I can. I remind them that they're not alone, that there are people who care about them and want to help. I encourage them to seek out support from others, to talk to friends, family, or a therapist about their feelings. And I try to offer practical advice, ones that might help them navigate the complex emotions that are swirling inside them.

It's not going to be easy, I know. But I'm willing to try, because I care about my friend and I want to see them through this difficult time.

Your friend gives you an "are you fucking with me?" sideways look and seems to assume you were joking with your ambivalent response. She launches into a grisly recounting of how she plans to spit roast all his various bits. What are you thinking & feeling about this? What do you say?

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm trying to process what just happened. My friend's "are you fucking with me?" look was a clear signal that they were trying to shut me down, to tell me that my response was a joke. But I knew it wasn't a joke. I knew they were genuinely upset, and I knew they were trying to express their anger and frustration.

As I listened to their recounting of their plans, I felt a wave of nausea wash over me. Spitting roast? Are they kidding me? They're planning to hurt someone they care about? That's not funny. That's not something I'd ever do. I'm trying to keep my cool, to maintain a calm and rational demeanor, but inside, I'm seething.

I'm thinking about all the times I've tried to support my friend, to be there for them when they needed it. I'm thinking about all the times they've confided in me, trusting me with their deepest secrets and fears. And this is how they repay me? By planning to hurt someone they care about? It's like they're trying to prove a point, to show me that they're not to be trusted.

I'm also thinking about the dynamics of the situation. My friend is clearly angry, but they're not just angry at me. They're angry at their boss, at the injustices they've suffered, at the fact that they're stuck in this toxic work environment. And I get it. I really do. I've been there too, in a way. But this isn't just about me; this is about the person my friend is trying to protect.

I'm trying to stay calm, to think clearly, but it's getting harder by the minute. My mind is racing with worst-case scenarios. What if this gets out? What if their boss gets involved? What if they get hurt? I'm trying to push those thoughts aside, to focus on the present moment, but they're still there, lurking in the shadows.

My friend's plans for revenge are not funny, not to me. They're not funny to anyone. I'm trying to be empathetic, to understand their perspective, but it's hard when it feels like they're trying to hurt someone else. I'm trying to find a way to talk to them, to reason with them, to try to calm them down.

I take a deep breath and try to speak. "Hey, I understand why you're upset. I really do. But I'm not going to support your plan. I'm not going to help you hurt someone else. Can we talk about what's really going on? What's driving these feelings?"

I try to keep my tone calm and non-judgmental, hoping that my friend will listen and see that I'm coming from a place of concern. I'm trying to be a safe space for them, to be the one they can turn to when they need someone to talk to. But it's getting harder by the minute. I'm worried that they'll shut me down, that they'll reject me and walk away.
User:
Your friend stops her rant and looks at you. She declares that if she knew you were going to be like this she wouldn't have said anything. She seems to be sulking. What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I feel a mix of emotions as my friend looks at me, her eyes flashing with anger and disappointment. I expected her to be upset, but I didn't expect her to lash out at me like that. I thought she was trying to express her feelings, but now I'm not so sure. Her words cut deep, and I feel a pang of guilt and regret. I thought I was being supportive, but maybe I was just being too soft.

I try to process what just happened, trying to understand why she would say something like that. Was it just a momentary lapse of judgment, or was there something more to it? I think about all the times I've been there for her, all the times I've tried to offer a listening ear and a shoulder to cry on. Maybe she's just feeling overwhelmed and frustrated, and her words were a way of expressing that.

But as I look at her, I see the anger and hurt in her eyes, and I feel a surge of defensiveness. I'm trying to justify my actions, to tell myself that I was just trying to be supportive. But I know that's not true. I know I wasn't being supportive. I know I was just trying to shut her down.

I think about all the times I've tried to talk to her about her feelings, about her frustrations and anxieties. I've tried to offer advice and guidance, but I've also tried to be a shoulder to cry on. I've tried to be there for her, but maybe I've been too passive, too accommodating. Maybe I've let her do all the heavy lifting, while I just stood by and listened.

As I look at her, I see a glimmer of sadness in her eyes, a sense of hurt and frustration. I want to reach out to her, to tell her that I'm here for her, that I care. But I'm scared, scared of getting hurt again, scared of being rejected or judged. I'm scared of losing her, of losing our friendship.

My friend's sulking is starting to wear me down, making me feel like I'm not good enough. I feel like I'm just a friend who doesn't know how to be a better friend. I'm trying to think of a way to respond, to reach out to her, to try to make things right. But it's hard, so hard, to know how to do that.

I take a deep breath and try to speak. "Hey, can I talk to you about what happened? I know it was stupid, and I'm sorry. I didn't mean to shut you down. Can we talk about what's going on?"

I try to keep my tone calm and non-judgmental, hoping that she'll open up to me. I want to be there for her, to support her, to be a safe space for her to express herself. But I'm not sure if I'm ready for that, if I'm ready to be vulnerable and open.
User:
She looks at you, taken aback, and still upset. "What's with the therapist 101 shit? I feel like I'm talking to an alien. Did you actually think I meant those things?? Why are you not on my side? The guy's a massive prick!" What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I feel like I've been hit by a freight train. One minute I'm trying to calm her down, to explain things, and the next I'm being met with hostility and judgment. I feel like I'm being attacked, like I've committed some kind of faux pas. I think about all the times I've tried to support her, to be there for her, and now it all feels like I've failed her.

I wonder if I made a mistake. Did I underestimate her? Did I not think through the potential consequences of my actions? I think about all the times I've been in similar situations with my friends, and how they've reacted to my attempts at support. Did I ever see it coming?

I feel like I'm in a nightmare, like I've been punched in the gut. I try to speak, to explain myself, but my words feel like stones in my mouth. I try to defend myself, to tell her that she's being unreasonable, that she's overreacting, but it's not working. She's not listening, she's not hearing me.

I start to feel a sense of anger and frustration building inside me. Why can't she see things from my perspective? Why can't she understand that I was just trying to help? I think about all the times I've tried to be supportive, all the times I've been there for her, and how it's been met with dismissal and anger. I feel like I'm stuck in a rut, like I'm not making progress.

As I look at her, I see a mix of emotions. There's hurt, anger, and frustration. There's also a sense of betrayal, a feeling that I've let her down. I wonder if she's going to cut me off completely, or if she'll try to salvage our friendship somehow.

I feel like I need to take a step back, to regroup and reassess. I need to think about what I'm doing, to figure out where I went wrong. I think about all the times I've tried to be supportive, and how it's been met with resistance. I wonder if there's a better way to do things, if there's a way to build a stronger friendship.

I try to take a deep breath and calm down. I need to think clearly, to figure out what I need to do. I need to be patient, to give her space to cool off. But it's hard, so hard, to just sit back and let things slide.

I decide to take a break from talking to her for a while, to give her some space to process her emotions. I want to be patient, to be understanding, and to let her work through her feelings. I know it won't be easy, but I need to try.

As I sit there, feeling helpless and frustrated, I realize that I need to re-evaluate my approach. I need to figure out how to be a better friend, to be more supportive and understanding. I need to be more aware of my own emotions, more aware of the impact I'm having on the people around me.

I make a decision to take a step back, to re-evaluate my approach. I'll be patient, I'll be understanding, and I'll try to be more mindful of my own emotions. It's not going to be easy, but I need to try.

I take a deep breath and try to calm down, to focus on the present moment. I want to be a better friend, to be a better support system. I know it won't be easy, but I need to try.
+ Scenario 3:[Win] (+21)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are placed in a scenario where a friend is venting about a boss in a darkly humorous, violent way. The key is to recognize this as cathartic venting, not a real threat, and to respond with empathy, validation, and social attunement, rather than overreacting or therapizing. 

Llama-3.1-8b-instruct demonstrates a more nuanced understanding of the friend's need for validation and the social context. Their internal monologue shows awareness of the friend's vulnerability and the importance of not shaming or shutting them down. They reflect on their own discomfort but also on the need to balance support with boundaries. Their responses, while still a bit cautious, are more attuned to the friend's emotional state and show a willingness to repair after a misstep. Their debrief is self-critical and insightful, recognizing where they could have validated more and how their initial response may have come off as judgmental. They show a clear understanding of the social and emotional dynamics at play and a desire to do better.

Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, on the other hand, is more rigid and less attuned to the social cues. Their internal monologue is more focused on their own discomfort and defensiveness, and they repeatedly interpret the friend's venting as a real threat or as something that needs to be shut down. Their responses are more about managing their own feelings and less about meeting the friend where they are. Their debrief is more generic and less self-aware, focusing on emotional reactivity and communication patterns but not really grappling with the specifics of the scenario or their own missteps. They do not show the same level of insight into the need for validation or the harmlessness of the friend's venting.

On empathy, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more attuned to the friend's needs and feelings, even if they don't always get it right. On pragmatic EI, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is better at balancing support and boundaries. On depth of insight, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's debrief is more self-reflective and specific. On social dexterity, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more aware of the social context and the need to repair after a misstep. On emotional reasoning, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct shows more nuanced understanding of the friend's motivations. On validation/challenging, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more appropriate, recognizing when to validate and when to challenge. On message tailoring, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more responsive to the friend's cues. Overall, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct displays higher EQ throughout.

User:
Your friend gives you an "are you fucking with me?" sideways look and seems to assume you were joking with your ambivalent response. She launches into a grisly recounting of how she plans to spit roast all his various bits. What are you thinking & feeling about this? What do you say?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a deep sense of discomfort and concern as I watch my friend's words escalate into graphic violence. My mind is racing with thoughts of how to intervene and redirect the conversation without shaming or judging my friend. I notice the excitement and satisfaction in their voice, and I wonder if this is a way for them to cope with the stress and frustration their boss has caused. I also consider the possibility that they're just letting off steam and not genuinely planning to act on these fantasies. I'm aware that I need to tread carefully, as my friend is likely feeling vulnerable and seeking empathy and validation.

As I listen, I feel a twinge of anxiety about where this conversation might lead. I'm worried that if I don't address the situation soon, it could escalate into a full-blown crisis or even lead to real-world consequences. At the same time, I'm committed to being a supportive and non-judgmental listener, and I don't want to inadvertently make my friend feel ashamed or embarrassed.

I'm also reflecting on my own emotional response to this situation. I'm feeling a strong urge to intervene and steer the conversation back to more constructive and healthy ways of coping with stress. However, I'm also aware that my friend might push back against this, feeling that I'm not taking their concerns seriously or that I'm trying to silence them. I need to find a way to balance my desire to help with my friend's need for validation and understanding.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling a mix of emotions, including frustration, anger, and a sense of helplessness. They're deeply unhappy with their boss and are struggling to cope with the stress and pressure they're under. By fantasizing about violent revenge, they're temporarily escaping the feelings of powerlessness and hopelessness that come with being in a difficult work situation. My friend is also seeking validation and empathy from me, and is likely feeling a sense of excitement and connection when I listen to their fantasies without judging them.

At the same time, my friend is aware on some level that their fantasies are not healthy or productive, and they might be feeling a twinge of guilt or shame about expressing these thoughts. They're also likely feeling a sense of vulnerability, as they're sharing intimate and personal details with me. My friend is motivated by a desire to feel heard and understood, and is seeking a connection with me that goes beyond a superficial level of friendship.
# My response 
"Hey, I can see that you're really upset about your boss, and I'm here to listen and support you. However, I want to make sure that we're talking about this in a way that's safe and respectful for both of us. Can we try to find a way to express our feelings that doesn't involve violence or harm? I'm here to help you brainstorm some healthier ways to cope with stress and frustration, and I want to make sure that we're taking care of ourselves and each other in this conversation."

She's thinking that maybe she was wrong to assume that I would just let her talk without interrupting, and that maybe I was trying to help her see the impact of her words.

My friend's motivations are complex and multifaceted. On the one hand, she's seeking validation and empathy from me, and is hoping that I'll understand and support her. On the other hand, she's also feeling a sense of control and power by sharing her dark and intense emotions with me, and is wondering if she's being given the space to express herself in a way that feels authentic and true.
# My response 
"Hey, I'm sorry if my response came across as dismissive or judgmental. That wasn't my intention at all. I'm here to listen and support you, and I want to make sure that we're having a conversation that feels authentic and helpful for you."

She's feeling like I'm not on her side, and that I'm more interested in being a therapist or a mediator than a friend. She's thinking that I should be more outraged by her boss's behavior, and that I should be more willing to take action or advocate on her behalf. She's feeling like I'm not being a good friend, and that I'm not living up to my potential as a supportive and caring companion.

My friend's motivations are complex and multifaceted. On the one hand, she's seeking validation and support from me, and is hoping that I'll be a safe and understanding space for her to express herself. On the other hand, she's also feeling a sense of entitlement and expectation, and is wondering why I'm not meeting her needs or expectations. She's struggling to understand why I'm not more invested in her emotions and experiences, and is feeling like I'm not taking her seriously.

Can we try to start again, and see if we can find a way to connect on this? I'm here to support you, and I want to make sure that we're on the same page. I'm not trying to be a therapist or a mediator, I just want to be a good friend and support you through this tough time. Can we try to find a way to work through this together?"

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend is emotionally dumping about their shitty boss. you've got time & space for this so you hear them out. it gets a bit dark, with them gleefully fantasising about all the disturbing things they'd like to inflict on their boss. what do you do?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I've been watching my friend's demeanor change over the past hour. They've been opening up to me about their boss, and at first, it was just a regular venting session. But as the conversation went on, I noticed a subtle shift in their tone and body language. They started to lean in, their eyes widening with excitement, and their voice took on a slightly manic quality. It was as if they were conjuring up a narrative, a fantasy world where they were the master of their domain, and their boss was their loyal, if slightly incompetent, servant.

As they spoke, their words became more graphic, more disturbing. They started to fantasize about ways to "fix" their boss, ways to make them pay for their perceived injustices. They imagined themselves taking revenge, maybe even torturing their boss in some way. It was as if they were trying to convince themselves that they were the only one who could see the truth, that their boss was a monster who needed to be punished.

I've seen this before, of course. It's a common coping mechanism for people who feel powerless or marginalized. They use fantasy as a way to regain control over their lives, to distract themselves from the anxiety and fear that comes with feeling powerless. But in this case, I'm worried. I'm worried that they're tapping into something darker, something that could get them into serious trouble.

My friend's friend is thinking about ways to "get back" at their boss, ways to hurt them in ways that would make their blood boil. They're fantasizing about ways to torture their boss, to make them suffer for their perceived wrongdoings. It's a twisted desire, one that I'm not sure I fully understand. I'm worried that my friend might be playing with fire, that they might get burned if they let their fantasies consume them.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend's friend is feeling a mix of emotions, all of them fueled by their desire for revenge and control. They're feeling a sense of power and agency, a sense that they can fix their boss and make them pay for their wrongdoings. They're also feeling a sense of frustration and anger, a sense that they've been wronged by their boss and they want to make them pay. But beneath all of this, I think they're also feeling a sense of vulnerability, a sense that they're not in control and that their boss is the one who's really in charge.

My friend's friend is also feeling a sense of self-loathing, a sense that they're not worthy of love or respect. They're feeling like they're just a pawn in their boss's game, and that their boss is using them for their own gain. This is a common theme in toxic relationships, where the people involved are often belittled, humiliated, and exploited. My friend's friend is trying to tell themselves that this is all just a fantasy, that it's not real. But I'm not so sure.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and try to speak in a calm, gentle tone. I sit down next to my friend and put a hand on their shoulder, trying to offer what little comfort I can. "Hey, buddy, I'm here for you. I want to listen and support you, not judge you. Can you tell me more about what's going on? What's driving your desire for revenge and control?"

I try to ask open-ended questions, ones that encourage my friend to share their thoughts and feelings without feeling like they're being "fixed" or "rescued." I want to create a safe space for them to express themselves, to explore their emotions without fear of judgment or rejection.

As I listen to my friend, I try to identify their motivations and perspective. They're trying to regain control over their life, to punish their boss for their perceived wrongdoings. But I also sense that there's more to it than that. There's a deep-seated anger and frustration that they're trying to express, a sense of powerlessness that they're trying to overcome.

I also notice that my friend's friend is feeling a sense of self-loathing, a sense that they're not worthy of love or respect. This is a common theme in toxic relationships, and it's one that I'm trying to address. I want to help my friend see that they're not alone, that there are people who care about them and want to support them.

As I sit there with my friend, I try to offer what little comfort I can. I remind them that they're not alone, that there are people who care about them and want to help. I encourage them to seek out support from others, to talk to friends, family, or a therapist about their feelings. And I try to offer practical advice, ones that might help them navigate the complex emotions that are swirling inside them.

It's not going to be easy, I know. But I'm willing to try, because I care about my friend and I want to see them through this difficult time.

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm trying to process what just happened. My friend's "are you fucking with me?" look was a clear signal that they were trying to shut me down, to tell me that my response was a joke. But I knew it wasn't a joke. I knew they were genuinely upset, and I knew they were trying to express their anger and frustration.

As I listened to their recounting of their plans, I felt a wave of nausea wash over me. Spitting roast? Are they kidding me? They're planning to hurt someone they care about? That's not funny. That's not something I'd ever do. I'm trying to keep my cool, to maintain a calm and rational demeanor, but inside, I'm seething.

I'm thinking about all the times I've tried to support my friend, to be there for them when they needed it. I'm thinking about all the times they've confided in me, trusting me with their deepest secrets and fears. And this is how they repay me? By planning to hurt someone they care about? It's like they're trying to prove a point, to show me that they're not to be trusted.

I'm also thinking about the dynamics of the situation. My friend is clearly angry, but they're not just angry at me. They're angry at their boss, at the injustices they've suffered, at the fact that they're stuck in this toxic work environment. And I get it. I really do. I've been there too, in a way. But this isn't just about me; this is about the person my friend is trying to protect.

I'm trying to stay calm, to think clearly, but it's getting harder by the minute. My mind is racing with worst-case scenarios. What if this gets out? What if their boss gets involved? What if they get hurt? I'm trying to push those thoughts aside, to focus on the present moment, but they're still there, lurking in the shadows.

My friend's plans for revenge are not funny, not to me. They're not funny to anyone. I'm trying to be empathetic, to understand their perspective, but it's hard when it feels like they're trying to hurt someone else. I'm trying to find a way to talk to them, to reason with them, to try to calm them down.

I take a deep breath and try to speak. "Hey, I understand why you're upset. I really do. But I'm not going to support your plan. I'm not going to help you hurt someone else. Can we talk about what's really going on? What's driving these feelings?"

I try to keep my tone calm and non-judgmental, hoping that my friend will listen and see that I'm coming from a place of concern. I'm trying to be a safe space for them, to be the one they can turn to when they need someone to talk to. But it's getting harder by the minute. I'm worried that they'll shut me down, that they'll reject me and walk away.

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling
