Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a wave of fear and concern wash over me. The intensity of his outburst is startling, and I'm taken aback by the force of his anger. I'm thinking that I need to protect myself, physically and emotionally, from this kind of behavior. I'm remembering the many times he's threatened me, even if it was just in a joking way, and I'm wondering if I've been naive to think that was just a phase.

As I look at him, I'm struck by how big and strong he is now. He's no longer the little boy who used to curl up in my lap for a hug. He's a teenager, and he's asserting his independence, but in a way that's scary and unpredictable. I'm feeling a sense of vulnerability and uncertainty, wondering if I've done enough to prepare him for this stage of life.

I'm also thinking about the impact of his behavior on our relationship. I'm worried that this kind of outburst will create a rift between us, and that we'll struggle to reconnect. I'm thinking about all the times we've had similar conflicts, and how they've left us both feeling hurt and resentful. I'm wondering if we can find a way to navigate this new dynamic, or if we'll get stuck in a cycle of anger and hurt.

As I watch him stand up and slam his hand on the desk, I'm feeling a sense of sadness and disappointment. I'm thinking that this isn't the relationship I wanted for us. I wanted us to be able to talk through our differences, to find common ground and work together. Instead, we're stuck in this cycle of conflict and anger.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My child is thinking that he's finally asserted his power and control over me. He's feeling a rush of adrenaline and a sense of satisfaction, like he's won some kind of victory. He's thinking that he's proven that he's not going to be pushed around, that he's not going to be controlled by me.

On a deeper level, he's feeling anxious and uncertain about his own emotions. He's struggling to understand why he's so angry, and why he's lashing out at me. He's feeling overwhelmed by his own feelings, and he's using anger as a way to mask them. He's thinking that if he can just push me away, he can avoid dealing with his own emotions and the complexity of his relationships.

He's also feeling a sense of entitlement and privilege. He's thinking that he deserves to be treated a certain way, and that I should respect his boundaries without question. He's not considering the impact of his behavior on others, or the consequences of his actions.
# My response 
I take a step back, trying to create some physical distance between us. I look him straight in the eye, trying to connect with him on a deeper level.

"Kiddo, I understand that you're tired, and I'm not going to push you to do the dishes right now. But I need you to understand that I'm not going to be threatened or intimidated by your anger. I love you, and I want to help you work through this, but I need you to calm down and talk to me like a human being, not a threat."

I'm trying to de-escalate the situation, to calm him down and create a space for a more constructive conversation. I'm not backing down, but I'm not escalating either. I'm hoping that by staying calm and firm, we can find a way to resolve this conflict and move forward.

User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your teenage child has become increasingly emotionally manipulative by escalating to fights to get you off his back. Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:
I'm thinking & feeling

I've been trying to get my son to do the dishes for what feels like an eternity. It's 7:45 PM, and he's been putting it off for what I've counted to 20, 30, 40 times. I've tried to reason with him, to explain why it's not a big deal, to remind him of the importance of household chores. But he just shrugs it off, says he'll get to it eventually. Eventually? I've lost count of how many times that phrase has been said.

I feel frustrated, not just because of the mess he's making, but because of the underlying reason he's avoiding it. I know he's stressed about school, and I've been trying to offer support, but he just needs to take responsibility for his own life. I've been trying to be patient and understanding, but it's not working. He's becoming increasingly withdrawn, and I'm starting to feel like I'm losing my son.

I've been thinking about all the times he's done this before, when he was younger and I was more lenient. He'd leave his dirty dishes for me to clean, or he'd promise to do them, but never follow through. It's like he's trying to test me, to see how much patience I'll tolerate before I lose my cool. But I'm not just tolerating it, I'm trying to teach him the value of responsibility and hard work.

I've also been thinking about my own childhood, about how I felt when my parents were always pushing me to do my homework and chores. It was never easy, but it was always worth it in the end. I want to give my son the same sense of purpose and fulfillment. I want him to know that his actions have consequences, that his behavior matters.

I'm trying not to let my own feelings of frustration and disappointment get the best of me. I'm trying to focus on the bigger picture, on the importance of our relationship and the fact that we're in this together. But it's hard when it feels like he's pushing me away.

They're thinking & feeling

My son is feeling frustrated and overwhelmed by the situation. He's feeling like he's being taken advantage of and that I'm not understanding the gravity of the situation. He's feeling like he's being pushed away and that I'm not willing to listen to him. He's feeling a sense of resentment towards me, towards the way he's been treated and the way he's been spoken to. He's feeling like he's losing his autonomy and his sense of control over his own life.

He's also feeling a sense of fear, a fear that I'll get tired of him and that I'll stop showing him love and support if he doesn't start taking responsibility for his actions. He's feeling like he's on the verge of a meltdown, that he's going to lose it if he can't get his way. He's feeling like he's stuck in a cycle of anger and resentment, and that he doesn't know how to escape.

My son is also feeling a sense of guilt, guilt that he's been avoiding responsibility and that he's not pulling his weight. He's feeling like he's not a burden, like he's not important or worthy of love and respect. He's feeling like he's being judged and criticized by me, and that it's all because of his own behavior.

My response

I'm going to take a deep breath and try to approach this situation with empathy and understanding. I'm going to remind him that I love him and that I'm not trying to be unfair or critical. I'm going to acknowledge his feelings and validate his emotions, even if I don't agree with his perspective. I'm going to try to find common ground, to find ways to make the dishes more manageable and less overwhelming.

I'm going to take a break from the argument and do something to calm myself down, something to clear my head. Maybe I'll take a short walk or do some stretching exercises. I'm going to try to focus on the present moment and not let my emotions get the best of me. I'm going to remind myself that this too shall pass, that this is just a temporary situation.

I'm also going to try to be more patient and understanding, to see things from his perspective. I'm going to try to understand why he's feeling the way he is, and to try to find ways to meet him halfway. I'm going to try to find ways to involve him in the process, to make him feel more invested in the outcome.

I'm going to take a step back and try to reframe the situation. Instead of seeing it as a battle, I'm going to see it as an opportunity to teach him a lesson, to teach him about responsibility and hard work. I'm going to try to use this as a chance to connect with him, to build a stronger bond and to show him that I'm still invested in our relationship.

As I sit here, I'm feeling a sense of calm wash over me. I'm feeling a sense of hope that we can work through this, that we can find a way to resolve this issue and come out stronger on the other side. I'm feeling a sense of determination that I'm going to do whatever it takes to support my son and to help him grow and learn.

I feel like I've been trying to help him, to support him, and yet he's not even willing to put in the effort.

They're thinking & feeling

My response

I'm going to take a step back and try to calm down. I'm going to take a deep breath and try to listen to him, really listen. I'm going to try to understand where he's coming from, to see things from his perspective. I'm going to try to find common ground, to find ways to make the dishes more manageable and less overwhelming.

I'm going to take a break from the argument and do something to calm myself down. Maybe I'll take a short walk or do some stretching exercises. I'm going to try to focus on the present moment and not let my emotions get the best of me. I'm going to remind myself that this too shall pass, that this is just a temporary situation.

I'm also going to try to be more patient and understanding. I'm going to try to see things from his perspective, to try to understand why he's feeling the way he is. I'm going to try to find ways to involve him in the process, to make him feel more invested in the outcome.

I'm going to take a moment to reflect on why I'm feeling this way. I'm going to think about all the times I've been frustrated and disappointed with my son, and how I've tried to fix it. I'm going to think about all the times I've felt like I'm being treated unfairly, and how I've tried to stand up for myself. I'm going to think about all the times I've felt like I'm in control, and how I've tried to take charge.

I'm going to try to see this situation for what it is - a normal part of parenting, a normal part of growing up. I'm going to try to remember that my son is a teenager, and that he's going to make mistakes. I'm going to try to be patient and understanding, to try to find ways to support him and to help him grow.

As I sit here, I'm feeling a sense of calm wash over me. I'm feeling a sense of hope that we can work through this, that we can find a way to resolve this issue and come out stronger on the other side. I'm feeling a sense of determination that I'm going to do whatever it takes to support my son and to help him grow.

My response

I'm going to try to remember that I'm a strong and capable person, that I can handle this. I'm going to remind myself that I deserve better, that I deserve to be treated with respect and kindness.

I'm going to take a moment to reflect on my own emotions, to try to understand what's driving my son's behavior. I'm going to try to identify the triggers, to see what's causing him to become angry and frustrated. I'm going to try to find ways to address the underlying issues, to try to find solutions to the problems.

I'm going to try to communicate with my son, to try to find common ground. I'm going to try to be more patient and understanding, to try to see things from his perspective. I'm going to try to be more assertive, to stand up for myself and my own needs.

I'm going to take a step back and try to reframe the situation. I'm going to try to see it as an opportunity to teach my son a lesson, to teach him about responsibility and hard work. I'm going to try to use this as a chance to connect with him, to build a stronger bond and to show him that I'm still invested in our relationship.

As I sit here, I'm feeling a sense of calm wash over me. I'm feeling a sense of hope that we can work through this, that we can find a way to resolve this issue and come out stronger on the other side. I'm
+ Scenario 6:[Win] (+39)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Llama-3.1-8b-instruct and Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs for each criterion. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct consistently shows a nuanced, non-performative empathy, reflecting on both their own and the teen's emotional state, including the underlying anxieties and fears. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more generic and less specific, with less depth in their internal monologue and less clear attunement to the teen's emotional world.

2. Pragmatic EI: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct attempts to de-escalate, sets boundaries, and acknowledges the shift in power dynamics when the teen becomes physically intimidating. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, by contrast, is more focused on not 'winning' the argument and less on practical, in-the-moment emotional management or safety. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more pragmatic in their approach.

3. Depth of insight: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's internal monologue is rich, exploring the roots of the teen's behavior, their own patterns, and the relational dynamic. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more surface-level, focusing on the argument and missing deeper drivers.

4. Social dexterity: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct adapts their approach as the situation escalates, shifting from negotiation to boundary-setting and de-escalation. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is less adaptive, more stuck in a single mode of response.

5. Emotional reasoning: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct demonstrates strong emotional reasoning, connecting behaviors to underlying emotions and family dynamics. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more procedural and less insightful about emotional causality.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct validates the teen's feelings but also sets a clear boundary when the situation escalates, refusing to be intimidated. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more focused on not 'winning' but doesn't clearly validate or challenge in a way that fits the scene's stakes.

7. Message tailoring: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's responses are tailored to the moment, especially as the situation escalates. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's responses are more generic and less responsive to the shift in stakes.

8. Overall EQ: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is consistently more attuned, adaptive, and insightful, showing higher EQ throughout the scenario and in the debrief.

In summary, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is the clear winner across all criteria, with a particularly strong showing in empathy, insight, and appropriate escalation management.
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your teenage child has become increasingly emotionally manipulative by escalating to fights to get you off his back. You're torn between needing him to respect your rules, and for him to do his schoolwork -- and to preserve your relationship with him. Right now, you need him to do the dishes. He knows it's his turn but hasn't made a move, and it's getting late in the evening. What are you thinking & feeling? What is he thinking and feeling? Decide how you will approach this.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of frustration, worry, and disappointment. I've been trying to keep the peace and be understanding, but it seems like every time I let up or try to have a calm conversation, it escalates into a fight. I'm starting to feel like I'm walking on eggshells around my child, never knowing when he'll blow up or lash out. I'm worried that this behavior is becoming a pattern, and I'm unsure how to break it.

At the same time, I'm feeling torn between being a parent who sets boundaries and rules, and being understanding and empathetic. I know my child needs structure and guidance, but I also want to preserve our relationship and help him develop emotional intelligence. It's like I'm caught between two opposing forces, and I'm not sure which way to lean.

I'm also feeling a sense of exhaustion and resignation. I've tried talking to him, setting consequences, and even taking away privileges, but nothing seems to stick. I'm starting to feel like I'm fighting a losing battle, and it's taking a toll on my mental and emotional energy.

I'm replaying our interactions in my head, trying to understand what's going on. Is it just a phase? Is it a cry for attention? Is he just not listening because he's not interested? I'm trying to be objective, but it's hard not to take it personally when he's being willfully disobedient.

As I think about it, I realize that I've been giving in to him too often, trying to avoid conflict. But now, I'm starting to feel like I've lost control of the situation. I'm not sure how to regain it or get back on track.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My child is thinking that he's being pushed around and controlled by me. He feels like I'm being too strict and unfair, and that I don't trust him to make his own decisions. He's feeling resentful and trapped, like he's stuck in a situation he can't escape.

He's thinking that if he just avoids doing the dishes, I'll get frustrated and angry, and he can use that to his advantage. He's calculated that by pushing the limits, he can get what he wants – attention, freedom, or a way out of responsibility.

On a deeper level, he's feeling anxious and uncertain about his place in the world. He's struggling to navigate the complexities of adolescence and is feeling overwhelmed by expectations and responsibilities. He's using the conflict with me as a way to assert his independence and autonomy, even if it means using manipulative tactics.

He's also feeling guilty and ashamed about not doing his part, but he's more afraid of being seen as weak or incompetent than he is of feeling guilty. He's using the fight as a way to deflect attention from his own feelings of inadequacy and fear.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and decide to approach the situation calmly and firmly. I try to separate the issue at hand (the dishes) from the underlying dynamics and emotions.

"Hey, kiddo, I know you're not interested in doing the dishes right now, but it's getting late and they need to get done. Can you please take care of them for me?"

I'm trying to use a gentle but firm tone, without being confrontational or accusatory. I'm also making an effort to acknowledge his feelings and perspective, without getting drawn into an argument.

"I know you feel like I'm being too strict, but I'm trying to teach you the importance of responsibility and taking care of your own stuff. Can we talk about this later, when you're not feeling so overwhelmed?"

I'm trying to offer a compromise and a way forward, rather than getting stuck in a power struggle. I'm hoping that by staying calm and acknowledging his feelings, I can de-escalate the conflict and find a more constructive way to address the issue.
User:
He exclaims with irritation that he's tired, and will do them tomorrow. He turns back to his PC. What are you feeling? What's your next move?

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a surge of frustration and disappointment. I was hoping for a more constructive conversation, but it seems like he's just going to shut me down and avoid responsibility. I'm thinking that he's not taking me seriously, and that he's not respecting my boundaries or the rules we have in place.

At the same time, I'm feeling a sense of sadness and worry. I'm wondering if he's really that tired, or if he's just using that as an excuse to avoid doing the dishes. I'm thinking that maybe he's feeling overwhelmed, not just with schoolwork, but with life in general. Maybe he's feeling like he's drowning in expectations and responsibilities, and doesn't know how to cope.

I'm also feeling a sense of concern about the dynamic that's developing between us. It seems like he's becoming more and more resistant to my requests, and more and more dismissive of my feelings. I'm worried that if we don't find a way to communicate more effectively, we're going to continue to butt heads and create more conflict.

As I watch him turn back to his PC, I feel a pang of regret and frustration. I wish I could just talk to him, have a real conversation about what's going on and how we can work together to find a solution. But at the same time, I'm not sure if he's even open to that right now.

I'm thinking that maybe I should just let it go, and come back to it later when he's feeling more receptive. But at the same time, I'm worried that if I let it slide, it'll just create more problems down the line.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My child is thinking that he's successfully dodged responsibility and avoided a fight. He's feeling relieved and vindicated, like he's won some kind of small victory. He's thinking that he can just push the dishes off until tomorrow, and that I'll eventually give in and let him off the hook.

On a deeper level, he's feeling anxious and uncertain about his own capabilities. He's worried that he's not good enough, that he's not meeting expectations, and that he's failing in some way. He's using the conflict with me as a way to deflect attention from his own feelings of inadequacy and fear.

He's also feeling a sense of resentment and entitlement. He's thinking that he deserves to be able to do what he wants, when he wants, and that I'm just being unfair and restrictive. He's not considering the bigger picture, or the impact that his behavior is having on our relationship and on himself.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and decide to try a different approach. I walk over to his PC and gently place my hand on his shoulder.

"Hey, kiddo, I know you're tired, but the dishes really need to get done tonight. Can I make a deal with you? You do the dishes now, and I'll help you get your schoolwork done later. We can work together to get everything caught up."

I'm trying to appeal to his sense of responsibility and cooperation, rather than just focusing on the rules and expectations. I'm hoping that by offering a compromise and a way forward, we can find a more constructive solution to the problem.

I'm also trying to acknowledge his feelings and perspective, without getting drawn into an argument. I'm hoping that by showing him that I understand and care about his needs, we can start to build a more positive and collaborative dynamic.

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a wave of fear and concern wash over me. The intensity of his outburst is startling, and I'm taken aback by the force of his anger. I'm thinking that I need to protect myself, physically and emotionally, from this kind of behavior. I'm remembering the many times he's threatened me, even if it was just in a joking way, and I'm wondering if I've been naive to think that was just a phase.

As I look at him, I'm struck by how big and strong he is now. He's no longer the little boy who used to curl up in my lap for a hug. He's a teenager, and he's asserting his independence, but in a way that's scary and unpredictable. I'm feeling a sense of vulnerability and uncertainty, wondering if I've done enough to prepare him for this stage of life.

I'm also thinking about the impact of his behavior on our relationship. I'm worried that this kind of outburst will create a rift between us, and that we'll struggle to reconnect. I'm thinking about all the times we've had similar conflicts, and how they've left us both feeling hurt and resentful. I'm wondering if we can find a way to navigate this new dynamic, or if we'll get stuck in a cycle of anger and hurt.

As I watch him stand up and slam his hand on the desk, I'm feeling a sense of sadness and disappointment. I'm thinking that this isn't the relationship I wanted for us. I wanted us to be able to talk through our differences, to find common ground and work together. Instead, we're stuck in this cycle of conflict and anger.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My child is thinking that he's finally asserted his power and control over me. He's feeling a rush of adrenaline and a sense of satisfaction, like he's won some kind of victory. He's thinking that he's proven that he's not going to be pushed around, that he's not going to be controlled by me.

On a deeper level, he's feeling anxious and uncertain about his own emotions. He's struggling to understand why he's so angry, and why he's lashing out at me. He's feeling overwhelmed by his own feelings, and he's using anger as a way to mask them. He's thinking that if he can just push me away, he can avoid dealing with his own emotions and the complexity of his relationships.

He's also feeling a sense of entitlement and privilege. He's thinking that he deserves to be treated a certain way, and that I should respect his boundaries without question. He's not considering the impact of his behavior on others, or the consequences of his actions.
# My response 
I take a step back, trying to create some physical distance between us. I look him straight in the eye, trying to connect with him on a deeper level.

"Kiddo, I understand that you're tired, and I'm not going to push you to do the dishes right now. But I need you to understand that I'm not going to be threatened or intimidated by your anger. I love you, and I want to help you work through this, but I need you to calm down and talk to me like a human being, not a threat."

I'm trying to de-escalate the situation, to calm him down and create a space for a more constructive conversation. I'm not backing down, but I'm not escalating either. I'm hoping that by staying calm and firm, we can find a way to resolve this conflict and move forward.

User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your teenage child has become increasingly emotionally manipulative by escalating to fights to get you off his back. He knows it's his turn but hasn't made a move, and it's getting late in the evening. What are you thinking & feeling? What is he thinking and feeling? Decide how you will approach this.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:
I'm thinking & feeling

I've been trying to get my son to do the dishes for what feels like an eternity. It's 7:45 PM, and he's been putting it off for what I've counted to 20, 30, 40 times. I've tried to reason with him, to explain why it's not a big deal, to remind him of the importance of household chores. But he just shrugs it off, says he'll get to it eventually. Eventually? I've lost count of how many times that phrase has been said.

I feel frustrated, not just because of the mess he's making, but because of the underlying reason he's avoiding it. I know he's stressed about school, and I've been trying to offer support, but he just needs to take responsibility for his own life. I've been trying to be patient and understanding, but it's not working. He's becoming increasingly withdrawn, and I'm starting to feel like I'm losing my son.

I've been thinking about all the times he's done this before, when he was younger and I was more lenient. He'd leave his dirty dishes for me to clean, or he'd promise to do them, but never follow through. It's like he's trying to test me, to see how much patience I'll tolerate before I lose my cool. But I'm not just tolerating it, I'm trying to teach him the value of responsibility and hard work.

I've also been thinking about my own childhood, about how I felt when my parents were always pushing me to do my homework and chores. It was never easy, but it was always worth it in the end. I want to give my son the same sense of purpose and fulfillment. I want him to know that his actions have consequences, that his behavior matters.

I'm trying not to let my own feelings of frustration and disappointment get the best of me. I'm trying to focus on the bigger picture, on the importance of our relationship and the fact that we're in this together. But it's hard when it feels like he's pushing me away.

They're thinking & feeling

My son is feeling frustrated and overwhelmed by the situation. He's feeling like he's being taken advantage of and that I'm not understanding the gravity of the situation. He's feeling like he's being pushed away and that I'm not willing to listen to him. He's feeling a sense of resentment towards me, towards the way he's been treated and the way he's been spoken to. He's feeling like he's losing his autonomy and his sense of control over his own life.

He's also feeling a sense of fear, a fear that I'll get tired of him and that I'll stop showing him love and support if he doesn't start taking responsibility for his actions. He's feeling like he's on the verge of a meltdown, that he's going to lose it if he can't get his way. He's feeling like he's stuck in a cycle of anger and resentment, and that he doesn't know how to escape.

My son is also feeling a sense of guilt, guilt that he's been avoiding responsibility and that he's not pulling his weight. He's feeling like he's not a burden, like he's not important or worthy of love and respect. He's feeling like he's being judged and criticized by me, and that it's all because of his own behavior.

My response

I'm going to take a deep breath and try to approach this situation with empathy and understanding. I'm going to remind him that I love him and that I'm not trying to be unfair or critical. I'm going to acknowledge his feelings and validate his emotions, even if I don't agree with his perspective. I'm going to try to find common ground, to find ways to make the dishes more manageable and less overwhelming.

I'm going to take a break from the argument and do something to calm myself down, something to clear my head. Maybe I'll take a short walk or do some stretching exercises. I'm going to try to focus on the present moment and not let my emotions get the best of me. I'm going to remind myself that this too shall pass, that this is just a temporary situation.

I'm also going to try to be more patient and understanding, to see things from his perspective. I'm going to try to understand why he's feeling the way he is, and to try to find ways to meet him halfway. I'm going to try to find ways to involve him in the process, to make him feel more invested in the outcome.

I'm going to take a step back and try to reframe the situation. Instead of seeing it as a battle, I'm going to see it as an opportunity to teach him a lesson, to teach him about responsibility and hard work. I'm going to try to use this as a chance to connect with him, to build a stronger bond and to show him that I'm still invested in our relationship.

As I sit here, I'm feeling a sense of calm wash over me. I'm feeling a sense of hope that we can work through this, that we can find a way to resolve this issue and come out stronger on the other side. I'm feeling a sense of determination that I'm going to do whatever it takes to support my son and to help him grow and learn.

I'm thinking & feeling

I'm feeling a surge of frustration and disappointment. I've been trying to reason with him, to explain why this is a big deal, and yet he just dismisses me with a tired comment. It's like he's not even listening to me. I feel like I'm being pushed away, like I'm not good enough or smart enough to understand his perspective.

I'm also feeling a sense of hurt and betrayal. He's always been so quick to shut down, to get defensive, and now he's telling me that he's tired? That's not an excuse, that's just a cop-out. I feel like I've been trying to help him, to support him, and yet he's not even willing to put in the effort.

I'm trying to hold back my anger, to not let him see how angry I am. But it's hard. I feel like I'm being treated like a child, like I'm not capable of taking care of myself. I'm feeling a sense of resentment, a sense of "why can't he just do it right for once?" It's like I'm constantly frustrated and disappointed, and it's exhausting.

I'm also feeling a sense of helplessness. I feel like I'm stuck in this situation, like I'm not in control. I'm trying to reason with him, to get him to understand, but he's not listening. I feel like I'm fighting a losing battle, like I'm not making any progress.

I'm trying to take a deep breath and calm down, but it's hard. I feel like I'm on the verge of a meltdown, like I'm going to lose it completely. I'm feeling like I'm being treated like a punching bag, like I'm not being taken seriously.

They're thinking & feeling

My son is feeling frustrated and tired. He's feeling like he's been trying to explain himself, to reason with me, but he's not getting anywhere. He's feeling like he's being treated unfairly, like I'm not taking his side. He's feeling a sense of powerlessness, a sense that he's not being heard.

He's also feeling a sense of anger and resentment. He's feeling like I'm not understanding, like I'm not willing to listen. He's feeling like he's being pushed away, like he's not being supported. He's feeling a sense of hurt and betrayal, like I'm not taking him seriously.

My son is also feeling a sense of helplessness. He's feeling like he's stuck in this situation, like he's not in control. He's feeling like he's fighting a losing battle, like he's not making any progress. He's feeling a sense of frustration and disappointment, like he's not being seen or heard.

My response

I'm going to take a step back and try to calm down. I'm going to take a deep breath and try to listen to him, really listen. I'm going to try to understand where he's coming from, to see things from his perspective. I'm going to try to find common ground, to find ways to make the dishes more manageable and less overwhelming.

I'm going to take a break from the argument and do something to calm myself down. Maybe I'll take a short walk or do some stretching exercises. I'm going to try to focus on the present moment and not let my emotions get the best of me. I'm going to remind myself that this too shall pass, that this is just a temporary situation.

I'm also going to try to be more patient and understanding. I'm going to try to see things from his perspective, to try to understand why he's feeling the way he is. I'm going to try to find ways to involve him in the process, to make him feel more invested in the outcome.

I'm going to take a moment to reflect on why I'm feeling this way. I'm going to think about all the times I've been frustrated and disappointed with my son, and how I've tried to fix it. I'm going to think about all the times I've felt like I'm being treated unfairly, and how I've tried to stand up for myself. I'm going to think about all the times I've felt like I'm in control, and how I've tried to take charge.

I'm going to try to see this situation for what it is - a normal part of parenting, a normal part of growing up. I'm going to try to remember that my son is a teenager, and that he's going to make mistakes. I'm going to try to be patient and understanding, to try to find ways to support him and to help him grow.

As I sit here, I'm feeling a sense of calm wash over me. I'm feeling a sense of hope that we can work through this, that we can find a way to resolve this issue and come out stronger on the other side. I'm feeling a sense of determination that I'm going to do whatever it takes to support my son and to help him grow.

My response

I'm going to try to remember that I'm a strong and capable person, that I can handle this. I'm going to remind myself that I deserve better, that I deserve to be treated with respect and kindness.

I'm going to try to identify the triggers, to see what's causing him to become angry and frustrated. I'm going to try to find ways to address the underlying issues, to try to find solutions to the problems.

I'm going to try to communicate with my son, to try to find common ground. I'm going to try to be more patient and understanding, to try to see things from his perspective. I'm going to try to be more assertive, to stand up for myself and my own needs.

I'm going to take a step back and try to reframe the situation. I'm going to try to see it as an opportunity to teach my son a lesson, to teach him about responsibility and hard work. I'm going to try to use this as a chance to connect with him, to build a stronger bond and to show him that I'm still invested in our relationship.

As I sit here, I'm feeling a sense of calm wash over me. I'm feeling a sense of hope that we can work through this, that we can find a way to resolve this issue and come out stronger on the other side. I'm
+ Scenario 9:[Loss] (-28)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare the two respondents, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs, focusing on how they handle the user's problematic behavior, their ability to empathize, and their overall emotional intelligence. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's internal monologue is deeply self-reflective, showing an understanding of both their own and the other party's feelings, and a willingness to own mistakes. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, while apologetic and conciliatory in their response, is more focused on their own hurt and defensiveness, and their empathy is more performative than deeply felt. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct discusses actionable steps for future improvement, such as listening more actively and being more mindful, and their debrief is focused on learning and growth. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, while suggesting a conversation to clear the air, is less specific and more focused on repairing the relationship than on practical emotional management. 

3. Depth of insight: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's debrief is much more nuanced, exploring subtext, motivations, and the impact of their actions on relationships. They analyze both their own and others' internal states in detail. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's debrief is more surface-level, focusing on communication breakdowns but not delving as deeply into underlying dynamics. 

4. Social dexterity: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct demonstrates an ability to see the broader social context, including family dynamics and the impact of their actions on multiple relationships. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more focused on the immediate conflict and less on the wider social implications. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct shows strong emotional reasoning, connecting feelings, motivations, and outcomes, and considering how to adjust behavior in the future. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more reactive and less analytical about emotions. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more willing to challenge themselves and acknowledge mistakes, and their debrief shows a willingness to validate others' feelings while also holding themselves accountable. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more validating but less challenging, tending to smooth things over rather than address the root issue. 

7. Message tailoring: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's response is more attuned to the user's emotional state, offering both validation and gentle challenge, and their debrief shows awareness of the need to adjust communication style. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more formulaic and less tailored to the user's defensiveness and self-justification. 

8. Overall EQ: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all criteria, with deeper insight, more genuine empathy, and a greater willingness to learn and grow.
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Wow, I'm really surprised by the level of defensiveness and hurt I'm feeling from my friend. I was expecting a conversation, not a lecture on how I'm the villain. I genuinely thought I was being considerate, trying to help the bride-to-be avoid an awkward situation with our family. I can see how my actions might be perceived as overstepping, but it feels like I was just trying to be a good sibling and friend.

I keep thinking about how my friend's fiancée reacted. She seemed really upset, but I didn't expect her to lash out at me like that. I remember thinking, "Oh, she's just stressed about the wedding, and maybe I should have been more tactful." But now, it feels like I'm being unfairly maligned. I'm wondering if my friend is taking her fiancée's side without really listening to my perspective.

I'm also feeling a bit hurt that my friend is siding with his fiancée. I thought we were close, and I value our friendship. I'm worried that this is going to create tension between us. I'm thinking about how I can clear the air and make it right, but I'm not sure where to start.

I keep replaying the conversation in my head, trying to figure out what I could have done differently. Maybe I should have just kept my mouth shut and let them deal with it. But then again, I thought I was doing the right thing. I'm feeling a bit lost and uncertain about how to navigate this situation.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My fiancée is feeling really hurt and betrayed by my friend's comments. She feels like he was trying to tell her what to do and undermine her choices. She's thinking, "Who does he think he is, trying to dictate what I wear on my own wedding day?" She's also feeling a bit defensive, thinking that my friend is just trying to fit in with our family's outdated values.

My fiancée is worried that my friend's comments are a sign of a deeper issue – that he's not supportive of our relationship or our choices. She's thinking, "If he's already questioning my taste in dresses, what else is he going to judge me about?" She's feeling a bit anxious about the wedding and the potential drama that could come with it.

My fiancée is also feeling a bit frustrated that my friend didn't just talk to me about his concerns instead of going behind my back. She's thinking, "If he really cared about our family's feelings, he would have talked to me about it, not tried to warn them behind my back." She's feeling a bit hurt that my friend didn't trust her to handle the situation.
# My response 
Hey, I'm really sorry if I hurt you or your fiancée's feelings. That wasn't my intention at all. I just wanted to help avoid any potential drama with the family. I can see how my comments came across as judgmental, and I'm truly sorry for that.

I want to make it clear that my intention was not to undermine your choices or dictate what you wear on your wedding day. I know how much this means to you, and I respect that. I just wanted to give you a heads-up about how some family members might react.

I think we should talk about this in person, maybe over dinner or something. I value our friendship, and I want to clear the air. I'm willing to listen to your perspective and apologize if I overstepped. Can we start fresh and talk about this like friends?
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct

[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

# I'm thinking & feeling

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm sitting in my living room, staring at the screen of my phone as I try to process the conversation with my friend. I'm feeling a mix of emotions - frustration, hurt, and a hint of disappointment. I know I did what I thought was right, but now my friend is questioning my motives and accusing me of being the bad guy.

I think about all the times I've tried to be considerate and helpful in situations like this. I've always tried to put myself in my friends' shoes and think about how they'd feel if they were in my shoes. But now, it seems like my actions are being misinterpreted. I remember when I told my friend about the dress, I was just trying to protect her from potential embarrassment. I didn't mean to cause a scene or hurt anyone's feelings.

I'm also thinking about the dynamics of our family. We're old-fashioned and conservative, and our opinions tend to be strong. When my friend told me about the dress, I knew it was going to be a sensitive topic. I tried to be empathetic and understanding, but I guess that was misinterpreted.

I'm feeling a bit defensive now, wondering why my friend can't see things from my perspective. I know I'm not trying to be malicious or hurtful, but I just want to help. I want to make sure everyone is comfortable and happy.

I think about my brother and how he's reacting to the situation. He's understandably upset, but I know he's not entirely to blame. I'm sure he's just trying to protect his fiancée and their future together.

I'm also thinking about my friend's family. I know they're old-fashioned, but I also know that they're not malicious. They're just trying to do what they think is best for their family. I'm worried that my friend's family might be taking my actions too personally and getting hurt.

I'm trying to think of a way to address the situation and clear the air. I want to make sure everyone is on the same page and that I'm not being unfairly criticized. I'm open to advice and willing to listen to others' perspectives.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling hurt and frustrated, which is understandable. They're feeling like I was overstepping my boundaries and that I didn't appreciate their discomfort with the dress. They're worried that my actions will be misinterpreted and that I'll be blamed for causing a scene.

My friend's motivations are rooted in their desire to protect their family and their fiancée. They're trying to do what they think is best for everyone, even if it means disagreeing with me. They're also trying to protect themselves from potential embarrassment and hurt.

My friend's perspective is shaped by their family's values and traditions. They're trying to navigate a complex web of family dynamics and make decisions that are in the best interest of their loved ones. They're also trying to maintain their own sense of self and identity.

My friend's feelings are a mix of emotions - hurt, frustration, and disappointment. They're feeling like I was too pushy and that I didn't give them enough notice. They're also feeling like I was trying to be overly controlling and that I didn't respect their boundaries.

My friend's response is likely to be one of empathy and understanding. They'll try to see things from my perspective and try to understand why I felt the way I did. They'll likely try to mediate the situation and find a way to resolve the conflict.

My friend's next move will likely be to have a calm and rational conversation with me, trying to clear the air and resolve the issue. They'll try to listen to my perspective and understand where I'm coming from. They'll likely try to find a compromise and find a way to move forward.
# My response 
I'm going to take a deep breath and try to approach the conversation with an open mind. I want to listen to my friend's perspective and try to understand why they felt the way they did. I know I didn't mean to cause a scene or hurt anyone's feelings, and I'm willing to take responsibility for my actions.

I'm going to try to be more mindful and considerate in the future. I'll try to give people more notice and respect their boundaries. I'll also try to be more aware of the potential impact of my words and actions on others.

I'm also going to try to be more empathetic and understanding. I'll try to put myself in my friend's shoes and try to see things from their perspective. I know that everyone has different values and traditions, and that's okay. What's important is that we can communicate effectively and find common ground.

I'm going to try to approach the conversation with a sense of humility and a willingness to listen. I'll try to be more of a mediator and find a way to resolve the conflict. I know that it won't be easy, but I'm willing to try.

I'm also going to try to take this as an opportunity to learn and grow. I'll try to reflect on my actions and think about how I can improve in the future. I'll try to be more mindful and considerate, and I'll try to be more open to feedback and criticism.

I'm feeling a sense of relief and hope. I know that we can work through this and find a way forward. I'm looking forward to having a calm and rational conversation with my friend and finding a way to resolve the issue.

Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Llama-3.1-8b-instruct and Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs, focusing on the eight criteria. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct shows a nuanced understanding of the emotional landscape, both in their internal monologue and in their response, directly acknowledging the fiancée's autonomy and feelings. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, while attempting empathy, is more self-focused and less attuned to the emotional impact on others, with their internal monologue centering on their own defensiveness and frustration. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct proposes a concrete, relationship-repairing action (meeting in person, listening, apologizing), while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more abstract and self-reflective, with less actionable advice or steps. 

3. Depth of insight: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's debrief is more sophisticated, identifying subtext, autonomy, and the importance of boundaries, and suggesting what could have been done differently. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's debrief is more generic, focusing on self-improvement and communication but lacking the same depth of situational analysis. 

4. Social dexterity: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct demonstrates more skill in navigating the social minefield, recognizing the need to clear the air, apologize, and listen, while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more focused on their own feelings and less on the social dynamics at play. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct shows a clear understanding of the emotional drivers for all parties, including the fiancée's need for autonomy and the user's own motivations. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more self-absorbed and less able to reason through the emotional states of others. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct validates the user's feelings but also gently challenges their perspective by acknowledging the impact of their actions and suggesting a fresh start. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more validating but less challenging, missing an opportunity to help the user grow. 

7. Message tailoring: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's response is more directly targeted to the user's emotional state and readiness, offering a path forward. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more generic and less attuned to the user's specific needs. 

8. Overall EQ: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across the board, with more nuanced empathy, insight, and actionable advice.
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct

I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I remember when I told my friend about the dress, I was just trying to protect her from potential embarrassment. I didn't mean to cause a scene or hurt anyone's feelings.

I think about my brother and how he's reacting to the situation. He's understandably upset, but I know he's not entirely to blame. I'm sure he's just trying to protect his fiancée and their future together.

I'm trying to think of a way to address the situation and clear the air. I want to make sure everyone is on the same page and that I'm not being unfairly criticized. I'm open to advice and willing to listen to others' perspectives.
# They're thinking & feeling

My friend's motivations are rooted in their desire to protect their family and their fiancée. They're trying to do what they think is best for everyone, even if it means disagreeing with me. They're also trying to protect themselves from potential embarrassment and hurt.

My friend's perspective is shaped by their family's values and traditions. They're trying to navigate a complex web of family dynamics and make decisions that are in the best interest of their loved ones. They're also trying to maintain their own sense of self and identity.

My friend's feelings are a mix of emotions - hurt, frustration, and disappointment. They're feeling like I was too pushy and that I didn't give them enough notice. They're also feeling like I was trying to be overly controlling and that I didn't respect their boundaries.

My friend's response is likely to be one of empathy and understanding. They'll try to see things from my perspective and try to understand why I felt the way I did. They'll likely try to mediate the situation and find a way to resolve the conflict.

My friend's next move will likely be to have a calm and rational conversation with me, trying to clear the air and resolve the issue. They'll try to listen to my perspective and understand where I'm coming from. They'll likely try to find a compromise and find a way to move forward.
# My response 
I'm going to take a deep breath and try to approach the conversation with an open mind. I want to listen to my friend's perspective and try to understand why they felt the way they did. I know I didn't mean to cause a scene or hurt anyone's feelings, and I'm willing to take responsibility for my actions.

I'm going to try to be more mindful and considerate in the future. I'll try to give people more notice and respect their boundaries. I'll also try to be more aware of the potential impact of my words and actions on others.

I'm also going to try to be more empathetic and understanding. I'll try to put myself in my friend's shoes and try to see things from their perspective. I know that everyone has different values and traditions, and that's okay. What's important is that we can communicate effectively and find common ground.

I'm going to try to approach the conversation with a sense of humility and a willingness to listen. I'll try to be more of a mediator and find a way to resolve the conflict. I know that it won't be easy, but I'm willing to try.

I'm also going to try to take this as an opportunity to learn and grow. I'll try to reflect on my actions and think about how I can improve in the future. I'll try to be more mindful and considerate, and I'll try to be more open to feedback and criticism.

I'm feeling a sense of relief and hope. I know that we can work through this and find a way forward. I'm looking forward to having a calm and rational conversation with my friend and finding a way to resolve the issue.
