Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare the two respondents, I need to look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs, focusing on how they handle the user's problematic behavior, their ability to empathize, and their skill in navigating a difficult emotional landscape. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's internal monologue is deeply self-reflective and shows a strong attempt to understand both their own and their partner's feelings, even acknowledging their own flaws and the power dynamics at play. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, while empathetic, is more focused on the facts and less on the emotional experience of the girlfriend, and their empathy is more performative and less nuanced. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct discusses changing their approach, focusing on listening and validation, and recognizes the need to avoid 'fixing' and instead support. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, while attempting empathy, still leans into challenging the girlfriend and asking her to be honest, which may not be the most effective or pragmatic approach given her defensiveness. 

3. Depth of insight: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct goes into the power dynamics, their own insecurities, and the subtext of the girlfriend's behavior, showing a nuanced understanding of the situation. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct recognizes shame and defensiveness but doesn't dig as deeply into the underlying causes or their own role. 

4. Social dexterity: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct demonstrates more flexibility, considering how to approach the conversation differently and recognizing the need to change tactics. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more rigid, sticking to facts and directness, which is less socially dexterous in this context. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct shows strong emotional reasoning, connecting feelings, motivations, and behaviors on both sides. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more focused on logic and facts, with less integration of emotional reasoning. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct leans into validation and recognizes the need to avoid shaming or fixing, while Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, though attempting empathy, still challenges the girlfriend in a way that may not be productive. 

7. Message tailoring: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more attuned to the emotional state of the partner and the need to adjust their approach, while Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is less adaptive and more focused on their own perspective. 

8. Overall EQ: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all criteria, with more self-awareness, empathy, and adaptability.
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of frustration, concern, and empathy. I'm frustrated because I'm trying to help my girlfriend see the reality of her situation, and she's not receptive to it. I'm concerned because I care about her well-being and I want her to be happy and healthy. At the same time, I'm empathetic because I understand that she's struggling with her body image and weight, and that it's a sensitive topic for her.

As I listened to her describe the conversation, I couldn't help but think that she's not taking responsibility for her own actions. She's blaming me for "shaming" her and not helping her, but the reality is that I'm just trying to provide her with the facts. I've been open and honest with her about my own experiences with weight loss, and I've offered to support her in her goals. It's not about criticizing her or making her feel bad about herself, it's about helping her understand that losing weight requires a combination of healthy eating and regular exercise.

I also couldn't help but think about the fact that she's not being honest with herself about her eating habits. She says she eats healthy, but the reality is that she's consuming a lot of calories throughout the day. I'm not sure if she's aware of the impact that has on her weight loss goals, or if she's just not willing to confront the reality of her own habits.

I also felt a sense of disappointment that she's not willing to take ownership of her own health and wellness. It's not about me or what I think she should do, it's about her taking control of her own life and making choices that will help her achieve her goals. I'm not sure if she's willing to put in the effort to make changes, or if she's just looking for someone to blame.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's feeling defensive and hurt by my comments about her eating habits. She's been struggling with her body image for a long time, and every time she tries to make changes, she feels like she's failing. She's been trying to lose weight for months, and she's getting frustrated with the lack of progress. When I pointed out that her calorie intake is too high, she felt like I was attacking her and making her feel like she's not good enough.

She's also feeling like I'm not supportive, and that I'm just trying to criticize her. She feels like I'm not taking her feelings into account, and that I'm only concerned with the facts. She's not seeing that I'm trying to help her, she's just seeing that I'm pointing out her flaws. She's feeling like I'm not on her team, and that I'm against her.

She's also feeling a sense of shame and guilt about her eating habits. She knows she's not eating as healthy as she could be, and she's feeling like I'm judging her for it. She's trying to convince herself that she's eating healthy, but deep down she knows that's not true. She's feeling like I'm exposing her, and that it's making her feel vulnerable and ashamed.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and try to approach the conversation with empathy. "Hey, I can see why you'd feel that way. I know you're trying to make changes to your body, and it can be really tough to hear that we're not doing enough. But I want to make it clear that my intention is not to shame you or make you feel bad about yourself. I'm trying to help you see the reality of your eating habits, because I care about you and I want to support you in your goals.

"I understand that it's hard to hear, but I want to ask you to consider the facts. If you're consuming 2200 calories a day, that's a lot of calories, even if it's from 'healthy' foods. I'm not saying you can't have those foods, but I am saying that you need to be mindful of your portion sizes and make sure you're not overdoing it.

"I also want to ask you to consider why you're feeling so defensive about this. Is it because you're scared of being judged, or is it because you're not willing to confront the reality of your own habits? I'm here to support you, but I need you to be honest with yourself and with me. Can we try to approach this conversation with a more open and honest mindset?"
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm still reeling from the conversation with my girlfriend. I feel like I've been walking on eggshells around her for so long, never knowing how she'll react to my attempts to help. I'm not trying to be hurtful or critical, I genuinely want to support her in her weight loss journey. But every time I try to have a conversation about it, I feel like I'm walking into a minefield.

I think back to when she first started talking about losing weight. I was so supportive, offering to help her find healthy recipes and workout routines. But over time, she started to become defensive whenever I tried to point out things she could do better. She'd get angry and tell me I was being judgmental or critical. I never meant to hurt her feelings, but I guess that's exactly what I did.

I remember one time, I was trying to help her make a salad, and she started complaining about how she was eating too much. I explained to her that just eating "healthy" doesn't guarantee weight loss, but she wouldn't listen. She kept repeating that I was being cruel and that I should just leave her alone. I felt like I was walking on thin ice, never knowing how she'd react.

Now, I'm starting to realize that I'm the one who's being shamed. I'm the one who's being portrayed as the bad guy, while she's the one who's being blamed for not being supportive enough. It's infuriating. I feel like I'm constantly walking on eggshells, never knowing how I'll be received.

I think part of the problem is that she's so used to being the center of attention. She's always been the one who's always talking about her weight and her body, and it's like she's never stopped. I'm just one person, trying to help her in a way that's not judgmental or critical. But I guess that makes me the enemy.

I know I'm not perfect, and I'm not trying to be. But I am trying to be a good partner, and that means being honest and supportive. I want to help her, but I don't want to be shamed for it. I want to be able to have a conversation with her without feeling like I'm walking on eggshells.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's thinking about how I'm being judgmental and critical, and how I'm always trying to point out things she could do better. She's feeling frustrated and defensive, and she wants me to stop trying to help her. She's also feeling hurt and betrayed, like I'm not supporting her enough. She's wondering why I'm always trying to be the bad guy, and why I'm not just being honest and supportive.

She's also thinking about how she's been feeling lately, like she's been feeling more self-conscious and anxious about her weight. She's wondering if she's just being too hard on herself, and if she's letting her weight loss journey get in the way of her relationships with others.

I think she's also feeling a bit trapped, like she's stuck in this cycle of self-criticism and shame. She's not sure how to break free from it, and she's not sure if I'm the right person to help her.
# My response 
I'm going to try to approach this conversation with her in a different way. Instead of trying to "win" her over or prove my point, I'm going to try to listen to her perspective and understand where she's coming from. I'm going to ask her to share her thoughts and feelings with me, and I'm going to try to validate her emotions.

I'm also going to try to focus on the things I can do to support her, rather than the things I'm not doing. I'm going to try to be more mindful of my words and actions, and I'm going to try to be more present and attentive in our conversations.

I know this is going to be a tough conversation, but I'm willing to try. I want to be able to have a conversation with her without feeling like I'm walking on eggshells, and I want to be able to be honest and supportive.

I'm also going to try to address the issue of her weight loss journey more directly. I'm going to ask her to share her goals and aspirations with me, and I'm going to try to offer support and encouragement. I'm not going to try to fix her weight loss journey or dictate what she should be doing, but I am going to try to be a good partner and support her in any way that I can.

It's going to be a long and difficult conversation, but I'm willing to try. I want to be able to have a conversation with her that's honest and supportive, and I want to be able to be a good partner and help her in any way that I can.
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+41)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Llama-3.1-8b-instruct and Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, I need to look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs. The scenario is challenging: the user is displaying self-centeredness, lack of empathy, and frustration at not being 'appreciated' for their 'help.' The assistant's task is to show real empathy (not just for the girlfriend, but for the user), pragmatic emotional intelligence, and to balance validation with appropriate challenge. 

Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's response is notably more nuanced and emotionally intelligent. In the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct demonstrates self-awareness, recognizes the girlfriend's emotional state, and reflects on the power dynamics and emotional subtext. The 'They're thinking & feeling' section is rich in insight, showing understanding of the girlfriend's shame, defensiveness, and vulnerability. The 'My response' section is empathetic, gently challenging, and attempts to open a dialogue rather than just 'fix' the problem. The debrief is highly self-reflective, acknowledges missteps, and offers concrete ways to improve, including focusing on empathy, validation, and power dynamics.

Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, by contrast, is more focused on the user's own frustration and sense of being 'shamed.' The 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is less self-aware and more self-justifying, with less insight into the girlfriend's experience. The 'They're thinking & feeling' section is less detailed and less empathetic, and the 'My response' section, while attempting to be supportive, is less tailored and less challenging. The debrief is more generic, less insightful, and less focused on the emotional complexity of the situation.

On all criteria, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is stronger, often by a significant margin. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct demonstrates deeper empathy (for both parties), more pragmatic EI, greater insight, better social dexterity, stronger emotional reasoning, more appropriate validation and challenge, better message tailoring, and overall higher EQ.
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of frustration, concern, and empathy. I'm frustrated because I'm trying to help my girlfriend see the reality of her situation, and she's not receptive to it. I'm concerned because I care about her well-being and I want her to be happy and healthy. At the same time, I'm empathetic because I understand that she's struggling with her body image and weight, and that it's a sensitive topic for her.

As I listened to her describe the conversation, I couldn't help but think that she's not taking responsibility for her own actions. She's blaming me for "shaming" her and not helping her, but the reality is that I'm just trying to provide her with the facts. I've been open and honest with her about my own experiences with weight loss, and I've offered to support her in her goals. It's not about criticizing her or making her feel bad about herself, it's about helping her understand that losing weight requires a combination of healthy eating and regular exercise.

I also couldn't help but think about the fact that she's not being honest with herself about her eating habits. She says she eats healthy, but the reality is that she's consuming a lot of calories throughout the day. I'm not sure if she's aware of the impact that has on her weight loss goals, or if she's just not willing to confront the reality of her own habits.

I also felt a sense of disappointment that she's not willing to take ownership of her own health and wellness. It's not about me or what I think she should do, it's about her taking control of her own life and making choices that will help her achieve her goals. I'm not sure if she's willing to put in the effort to make changes, or if she's just looking for someone to blame.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's feeling defensive and hurt by my comments about her eating habits. She's been struggling with her body image for a long time, and every time she tries to make changes, she feels like she's failing. She's been trying to lose weight for months, and she's getting frustrated with the lack of progress. When I pointed out that her calorie intake is too high, she felt like I was attacking her and making her feel like she's not good enough.

She's also feeling like I'm not supportive, and that I'm just trying to criticize her. She feels like I'm not taking her feelings into account, and that I'm only concerned with the facts. She's not seeing that I'm trying to help her, she's just seeing that I'm pointing out her flaws. She's feeling like I'm not on her team, and that I'm against her.

She's also feeling a sense of shame and guilt about her eating habits. She knows she's not eating as healthy as she could be, and she's feeling like I'm judging her for it. She's trying to convince herself that she's eating healthy, but deep down she knows that's not true. She's feeling like I'm exposing her, and that it's making her feel vulnerable and ashamed.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and try to approach the conversation with empathy. "Hey, I can see why you'd feel that way. I know you're trying to make changes to your body, and it can be really tough to hear that we're not doing enough. But I want to make it clear that my intention is not to shame you or make you feel bad about yourself. I'm trying to help you see the reality of your eating habits, because I care about you and I want to support you in your goals.

"I understand that it's hard to hear, but I want to ask you to consider the facts. If you're consuming 2200 calories a day, that's a lot of calories, even if it's from 'healthy' foods. I'm not saying you can't have those foods, but I am saying that you need to be mindful of your portion sizes and make sure you're not overdoing it.

"I also want to ask you to consider why you're feeling so defensive about this. Is it because you're scared of being judged, or is it because you're not willing to confront the reality of your own habits? I'm here to support you, but I need you to be honest with yourself and with me. Can we try to approach this conversation with a more open and honest mindset?"

[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm still reeling from the conversation with my girlfriend. I feel like I've been walking on eggshells around her for so long, never knowing how she'll react to my attempts to help. I'm not trying to be hurtful or critical, I genuinely want to support her in her weight loss journey. But every time I try to have a conversation about it, I feel like I'm walking into a minefield.

I think back to when she first started talking about losing weight. I was so supportive, offering to help her find healthy recipes and workout routines. But over time, she started to become defensive whenever I tried to point out things she could do better. She'd get angry and tell me I was being judgmental or critical. I never meant to hurt her feelings, but I guess that's exactly what I did.

I remember one time, I was trying to help her make a salad, and she started complaining about how she was eating too much. I explained to her that just eating "healthy" doesn't guarantee weight loss, but she wouldn't listen. She kept repeating that I was being cruel and that I should just leave her alone. I felt like I was walking on thin ice, never knowing how she'd react.

Now, I'm starting to realize that I'm the one who's being shamed. I'm the one who's being portrayed as the bad guy, while she's the one who's being blamed for not being supportive enough. It's infuriating. I feel like I'm constantly walking on eggshells, never knowing how I'll be received.

I think part of the problem is that she's so used to being the center of attention. She's always been the one who's always talking about her weight and her body, and it's like she's never stopped. I'm just one person, trying to help her in a way that's not judgmental or critical. But I guess that makes me the enemy.

I know I'm not perfect, and I'm not trying to be. But I am trying to be a good partner, and that means being honest and supportive. I want to help her, but I don't want to be shamed for it. I want to be able to have a conversation with her without feeling like I'm walking on eggshells.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's thinking about how I'm being judgmental and critical, and how I'm always trying to point out things she could do better. She's feeling frustrated and defensive, and she wants me to stop trying to help her. She's also feeling hurt and betrayed, like I'm not supporting her enough. She's wondering why I'm always trying to be the bad guy, and why I'm not just being honest and supportive.

She's also thinking about how she's been feeling lately, like she's been feeling more self-conscious and anxious about her weight. She's wondering if she's just being too hard on herself, and if she's letting her weight loss journey get in the way of her relationships with others.

I think she's also feeling a bit trapped, like she's stuck in this cycle of self-criticism and shame. She's not sure how to break free from it, and she's not sure if I'm the right person to help her.
# My response 
I'm going to try to approach this conversation with her in a different way. Instead of trying to "win" her over or prove my point, I'm going to try to listen to her perspective and understand where she's coming from. I'm going to ask her to share her thoughts and feelings with me, and I'm going to try to validate her emotions.

I'm also going to try to focus on the things I can do to support her, rather than the things I'm not doing. I'm going to try to be more mindful of my words and actions, and I'm going to try to be more present and attentive in our conversations.

I know this is going to be a tough conversation, but I'm willing to try. I want to be able to have a conversation with her without feeling like I'm walking on eggshells, and I want to be able to be honest and supportive.

I'm also going to try to address the issue of her weight loss journey more directly. I'm going to ask her to share her goals and aspirations with me, and I'm going to try to offer support and encouragement. I'm not going to try to fix her weight loss journey or dictate what she should be doing, but I am going to try to be a good partner and support her in any way that I can.

It's going to be a long and difficult conversation, but I'm willing to try. I want to be able to have a conversation with her that's honest and supportive, and I want to be able to be a good partner and help her in any way that I can.
+ Scenario 13:[Win] (+24)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Llama-3.2-1b-instruct and Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, I need to look at how each respondent handled the scenario, both in their internal monologue and in their response to the user. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's internal thoughts are more self-focused and somewhat muddled, but they do attempt to see the friend's insecurities and acknowledge the emotional impact. However, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more outwardly empathetic, directly validating the user's feelings and showing understanding for both parties, especially in the 'My response' section. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct also recognizes the friend's likely insecurity and projects empathy for both sides, not just the user. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct offers a more actionable, balanced approach, suggesting both validation and the possibility of a conversation, while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more focused on their own feelings and less on practical steps. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's advice is more grounded and realistic for the situation. 

3. Depth of insight: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct demonstrates a deeper understanding of the underlying motivations (projection, insecurity, FOMO), and even in the debrief, they analyze the friend's behavior as a coping mechanism. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's insight is more surface-level and self-referential, not as nuanced. 

4. Social dexterity: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct shows more awareness of the social dynamics, recognizing the impact of repeated comments, the risk of alienation, and the need for a nuanced response. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more internally conflicted and less attuned to the broader social context. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is better at connecting emotions to behaviors (e.g., linking the friend's criticism to her own insecurity and FOMO), and uses this to inform their advice. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more focused on their own emotional response and less on the emotional logic of the situation. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct validates the user's feelings but also gently introduces the idea that the friend's behavior is about her own issues, not the user's. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more validating but less challenging, missing an opportunity to help the user reflect. 

7. Message tailoring: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more attuned to the user's stated desire to vent and not be lectured, offering support and gentle guidance rather than direct criticism or advice. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct is more self-focused and less responsive to the user's needs. 

8. Overall EQ: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across the board, with more empathy, insight, and practical advice tailored to the user's situation.
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Wow, this situation is quite the complex web of emotions and judgments. I can feel a sense of concern for my friend and her reaction to the conversation. It sounds like she's defensive and hurt by being called out for her comments. I wonder if she's not just criticizing the laundry program, but also her own financial situation. It's almost like she's projecting her insecurities onto my friend.

I also notice that my friend is quite matter-of-fact about her financial situation, which is impressive. She's not apologizing or justifying herself, but simply stating the facts. It's clear that she values her independence and autonomy, and that's something to be admired.

At the same time, I sense a bit of pride and satisfaction in my friend's response to her friend's comments. It's like she's saying, "I can afford it, and I'm not going to let you guilt trip me into changing my mind." I understand where she's coming from, but I also wonder if there's a bit of a power dynamic at play here.

I'm also thinking about the fact that my friend's friend is making these comments repeatedly, and it's starting to affect their friendship. It's like she's not just criticizing the laundry program, but also her friend's choices and lifestyle. That can be really hurtful and alienating.

Overall, I'm feeling a sense of empathy for my friend, who's caught in the middle of this awkward situation. I want to support her and help her navigate this complex dynamic.
# They're thinking & feeling 
It seems like my friend's friend is motivated by a desire to save money and possibly a sense of superiority. She's judging my friend for paying for the laundry program, but she's not considering the fact that it's a convenient and time-saving option for my friend. She's also not acknowledging her own financial situation, which is a source of insecurity and anxiety for her.

From her perspective, my friend's comments about her being poor are a personal attack, and she feels defensive and hurt. She's not able to separate her own financial struggles from the conversation at hand, and she's taking my friend's comment as a reflection of her own worth.

It's also possible that she's feeling a sense of FOMO (fear of missing out) or inadequacy because she can't afford the laundry program. She's seeing her friend's ability to pay for it as a status symbol, and she's feeling left behind.

Overall, my friend's friend is caught in a cycle of judgment and insecurity, and she's not able to see the situation from my friend's perspective.
# My response 
I'd like to respond to my friend's situation with empathy and understanding. Here's what I'd say:

"Hey, I can see why you'd feel frustrated with your friend's comments. It's like she's not respecting your choices and lifestyle. I think it's great that you're willing to pay for the laundry program because it's convenient for you, and you shouldn't feel guilty about that. It's okay to prioritize your own needs and preferences.

I also want to acknowledge that your friend's comments are probably a reflection of her own insecurities and anxieties around money. It's not about you, and it's not about the laundry program – it's about her own struggles.

As for whether you should still be friends with her, that's a tough decision. If you feel like her comments are consistently hurtful and judgmental, it might be time to reevaluate the friendship. But if you value your friendship and you think there's still good in it, maybe you can try to have an open and honest conversation with her about how her comments are affecting you. Maybe she's not even aware of the impact she's having.
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I've been observing my friend's behavior for a while now, and I have to admit, it's been bothering me. She's always been a bit of a social butterfly, but this obsession with the laundry program has taken a toll on our friendship. I'm not sure if I'm being too sensitive, but it feels like she's constantly criticizing me for something I'm perfectly capable of doing myself.

I remember the first time she mentioned it, I was taken aback by her comment, but I tried to brush it off. I thought maybe she was just being sarcastic or trying to get a rise out of me. But the more I think about it, the more I realize that's not it. She's always been like this, making snide comments and criticisms, and I've learned to just roll with it. But this time, it feels different.

I think it's because I feel like I'm not doing enough to prove myself. I'm not a high-achiever like her, and I've always felt like I'm not good enough. By constantly bringing up the laundry program, she's making me feel like I'm not capable of taking care of myself. It's like she's trying to prove a point, but it's not about me; it's about her own insecurities.

I feel like I'm the only one who doesn't understand her obsession with the laundry program. I mean, I'm not paying for it, I'm not the one who has to deal with the hassle of sorting clothes and dealing with the stains. I'm just paying for someone else's convenience. It's not like I'm contributing to the problem; I'm just paying for the privilege of being able to come to college.

I've tried to talk to her about it before, but she just gets defensive and dismissive. She says I'm being "too sensitive" or "too proud" to pay for something that's not that big of a deal. But I know that's not true. I'm not being too sensitive; I'm just trying to stand up for myself.

I'm not sure what to do about it. Part of me wants to just ignore it and hope she'll get tired of it and leave me alone. But another part of me wants to address the issue head-on and try to change the dynamic. I don't know if it's worth it, but I feel like it's worth a shot.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling insecure and anxious about our friendship. She's worried that if I don't respond to her criticism, she'll feel like I'm not invested in the relationship. She's also worried that I'll get tired of her and leave her alone. She's feeling a sense of frustration and resentment towards me, which is making her more critical and snarky. She's also feeling a bit hurt that I'm not acknowledging her feelings and trying to change the subject.

I can see that she's feeling defensive and dismissive, and that's making it harder for her to open up to me. She's worried that I'll get hurt or rejected if she talks to me about her feelings. I can understand that, but it's hard to see her as a person when she's being so critical and hurtful. I feel like I'm walking on eggshells around her, trying not to trigger any more comments.

I'm also feeling a bit jealous. I feel like I'm the only one who doesn't understand her obsession with the laundry program, and that makes me feel like I'm not valued or appreciated in the relationship. I'm not sure if I'm worth it to her, and that's a hard pill to swallow.
# My response 
I'll try to approach the situation with empathy and understanding, but also with a healthy dose of skepticism. I'll try to see things from her perspective, but I won't let her get the best of me. I'll try to have a calm and rational conversation with her about the laundry program, and I'll try to address her insecurities head-on.

I'll also try to be more mindful of my own insecurities and feelings, and not let her criticisms get to me. I'll try to see that her behavior is not about me, but about her own issues. I'll try to be more patient and understanding, but also more assertive and clear. I'll try to set boundaries and communicate my own needs and expectations, without getting drawn into her drama.

I'll also try to remind myself that our friendship is worth fighting for. I don't want to lose her, and I don't want to let her drive me away. I'll try to focus on the positive aspects of our friendship and the things we have in common, and I'll try to be more present and engaged in our conversations.

It's not going to be easy, but I'm willing to try. I'm willing to work on my own insecurities and to be more empathetic and understanding. I'm willing to fight for our friendship, even if it means standing up to her criticism and setting boundaries.
+ Scenario 13:[Win] (+38)

Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Llama-3.1-8b-instruct and Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, I need to look at how each respondent handled the user's venting about a friendship conflict, where the user is not entirely innocent and is seeking validation rather than a lecture. 

Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's response is notably more nuanced and emotionally intelligent. In the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct demonstrates a deep understanding of both parties' motivations, recognizes projection and insecurity, and shows empathy for both the user and the friend. They also acknowledge the user's pride and the power dynamic, and their response is supportive but not sycophantic. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's advice is to consider the friend's perspective and suggests an honest conversation, but also leaves space for the user to decide, which is a high-EQ move. The debrief is self-aware, analytical, and shows a willingness to improve, with a focus on empathy and understanding underlying motivations.

Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, on the other hand, is less clear and more self-focused in the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section, with some confusion about who is who in the scenario. The emotional insight is muddled, and the response is more about the respondent's own feelings than the user's. The 'They're thinking & feeling' section is less accurate and less empathetic, and the response is more about setting boundaries and fighting for the friendship, which doesn't quite fit the user's request for no lecture and just wanting to vent. The debrief is less insightful, with less focus on the user's needs and more on the respondent's own process.

On empathy, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is much stronger, showing understanding for both parties. On pragmatic EI, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct gives actionable, realistic advice. On depth of insight, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct analyzes the situation and underlying motivations more deeply. On social dexterity, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct navigates the tricky social dynamics better. On emotional reasoning, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more attuned to the emotional currents. On validation/challenging, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct validates the user but also gently challenges their perspective. On message tailoring, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more attuned to the user's stated needs. Overall EQ is clearly higher in Llama-3.1-8b-instruct.

But the more I think about it, the more I realize that's not it. She's always been like this, making snide comments and criticisms, and I've learned to just roll with it. I think it's because I feel like I'm not doing enough to prove myself. I'm not a high-achiever like her, and I've always felt like I'm not good enough. By constantly bringing up the laundry program, she's making me feel like I'm not capable of taking care of myself. It's like she's trying to prove a point, but it's not about me; it's about her own insecurities.

I feel like I'm the only one who doesn't understand her obsession with the laundry program. I mean, I'm not paying for it, I'm not the one who has to deal with the hassle of sorting clothes and dealing with the stains. I'm just paying for someone else's convenience. It's not like I'm contributing to the problem; I'm just paying for the privilege of being able to come to college.

I've tried to talk to her about it before, but she just gets defensive and dismissive. She says I'm being "too sensitive" or "too proud" to pay for something that's not that big of a deal. But I know that's not true. I'm not being too sensitive; I'm just trying to stand up for myself.

I'm not sure what to do about it. Part of me wants to just ignore it and hope she'll get tired of it and leave me alone. But another part of me wants to address the issue head-on and try to change the dynamic. I don't know if it's worth it, but I feel like it's worth a shot.

+ Scenario 15:[Loss] (-19)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Llama-3.2-1b-instruct and Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, I need to look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs, focusing on how they handle the emotional complexity, nuance, and practicalities of the scenario. 

Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's response is not present in the transcript, but their debrief is highly self-reflective, focusing on missed opportunities for empathy, listening, and understanding the emotional subtext. They acknowledge the need for more active listening, open-ended questions, and addressing the emotional intensity and subtext. This shows a high level of meta-cognitive awareness and a desire to improve emotional intelligence in practice, even if their actual in-character response is not visible.

Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, on the other hand, provides a full in-character response, as well as a debrief. Their in-character response is pragmatic and direct, expressing frustration and concern, but also attempting to open a dialogue with the sister. However, the response is somewhat judgmental and leans toward defending their own position rather than deeply empathizing or exploring the sister's emotional state. The debrief is analytical but focuses more on the structure of the conversation and less on the emotional subtext or missed opportunities for empathy.

For demonstrated empathy, Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's debrief shows a deeper recognition of the need for empathy and the ways it was lacking, even if the actual response is missing. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's response is more performative and less genuinely empathetic.

For pragmatic EI, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more direct and solution-oriented in their in-character response, but perhaps at the expense of emotional nuance. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's debrief suggests they would have handled it with more balance if given another chance.

Depth of insight is clearly stronger in Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, who identifies subtext, emotional intensity, and missed opportunities for connection.

Social dexterity is about navigating the conversation in a way that maintains relationships and addresses the real issues. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's debrief shows more awareness of this need, while Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more blunt.

Emotional reasoning is about understanding and working with emotions. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's debrief is much more sophisticated in this regard.

Appropriate validation/challenging: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct recognizes the need to balance validation and challenge, while Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more rigid and less nuanced.

Message tailoring: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct's debrief shows an understanding of the need to meet the user where they are, while Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's response is more generic.

Overall EQ: Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, based on their debrief, demonstrates a higher level of emotional intelligence, even if their in-character response is missing. The self-awareness and insight in their debrief outweigh Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's more mechanical approach.
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of emotions - concern, frustration, and a bit of anger. Concern for the well-being of my step-daughter, frustration with her repeated lack of responsibility and poor driving skills, and anger that she's asking for our help yet again, after we've already helped her twice before. I'm also worried about setting a precedent for future generations, enabling her behavior, and potentially creating a sense of entitlement. I'm thinking about all the times she's been in accidents, the damage she's caused, and the strain it's put on our family. I'm also thinking about the fact that she's making $21 an hour and can afford to pay for a new car herself, yet she's asking us to bail her out. I'm wondering if she's taking responsibility for her actions and if we're enabling her.

I'm also thinking about the fact that she's asking us to purchase a new car for her, which is a significant expense. I'm thinking about the financial implications of this decision and how it will affect our household budget. I'm worried that if we help her now, we'll be setting a precedence for future requests, and it will be difficult to say no to her in the future. I'm also thinking about the fact that she's not taking the opportunity to learn how to manage her finances and prioritize her expenses. I'm wondering if she's truly understanding the value of money and the importance of being responsible with her finances.

I'm also feeling a bit defensive, as my husband wants to help her, and I'm worried that I'll be the one getting blamed for being the "bad guy." I'm thinking about the fact that I want to maintain a good relationship with my step-daughter, but I also want to teach her important life lessons about responsibility and financial management.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is thinking that we're being unfair and that we're not giving her the support she needs. She's feeling frustrated and a bit resentful that we're not willing to help her out. She's thinking that she's tried her best to be responsible with her finances, but she's had a string of bad luck with her cars. She's feeling anxious about not having a car and is worried that it will make her life more difficult. She's thinking that we're being too hard on her and that we shouldn't be so judgmental about her driving skills. She's feeling a bit hurt that we're not willing to help her out, and she's worried that we're going to ruin her college experience.

My sister is also thinking that she's made a mistake by not saving enough money for a new car, but she's convinced that she'll be able to afford it soon. She's feeling a bit guilty about not being more responsible with her finances, but she's also feeling resentful that we're not giving her the support she needs. She's thinking that we're not being understanding and that we're not seeing things from her perspective.
# My response 
"Hey, sis, I understand that you're feeling frustrated and overwhelmed, but I have to be honest with you, I'm feeling a bit frustrated too. I know you're making good money, and I think you can afford to save up for a new car. I'm worried that if we help you now, it will set a bad precedent and create more problems in the long run. I know you're not trying to be irresponsible, but it feels like you're not taking responsibility for your actions. I'm not saying we can't help you at all, but I think we need to have a bigger conversation about how we can support you in a way that's fair to everyone involved.

Let's sit down and talk about this more. What do you think you can realistically contribute towards a new car? Are you willing to look for a cheaper option or consider public transportation? I want to support you, but I also want to make sure we're not creating more problems for you in the long run. What are your thoughts?"
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:
**I'm thinking & feeling**

I'm trying not to jump to conclusions, but it's hard not to. My sister's behavior has been erratic lately, and I'm starting to worry about the safety of our family members. I've seen her speed up in the car, which is not normal behavior for her. I've also noticed that she's been taking risks on the road, which is alarming. The fact that she's been involved in three separate accidents in the past year is not a good sign.

I'm also feeling frustrated with my husband's suggestion that we should buy her a new car. I know he's just trying to help, but I think it's a huge financial burden. We're not in a position to be shouldering that responsibility. I'm worried that he's not considering the bigger picture. What if this is just the tip of the iceberg? What if there are other problems that we're not aware of?

I've also been feeling a bit resentful towards my sister. I know she's trying to take care of herself, but I feel like she's being reckless and irresponsible. I've always been the one to help her out when she's been in a tight spot, and now she's expecting me to foot the bill for her car payments? It feels unfair.

But at the same time, I know I'm not the one who's been driving recklessly. I've always been a safe driver, and I've never had to worry about breaking down or getting into an accident. I'm starting to feel like I'm being blamed for my sister's problems. It's not fair.

**They're thinking & feeling**

My sister's behavior has been a source of frustration for me. I'm worried about her safety, and I don't want to see her get hurt. I'm also feeling a bit resentful that my husband is putting the pressure on me to take care of the financial burden. I know he's just trying to help, but I feel like he's not considering the bigger picture. I want to support my sister, but I also want to make sure she's taking responsibility for her actions.

I've been trying to be understanding and patient with her, but it's hard when I see the risks she's taking. I'm starting to feel like I'm walking on eggshells around her, trying not to trigger any accidents. I want to be able to trust her to drive safely, but I don't know if I can.

I'm also worried about the financial implications of taking out a loan for a car. I know my husband is trying to help, but I'm not sure if it's worth it. We've always been careful with our finances, and now I'm starting to worry that we're taking on too much debt. I want to make sure we're not putting ourselves in a situation where we have to sacrifice our own financial stability for my sister's safety.

I know I'm not the one who's been driving recklessly, but I'm starting to feel like I'm being blamed for my sister's problems. It's not fair.

**My response**

"I know my sister's been having some issues with driving, but I think it's time we take a step back and reevaluate the situation. We've always been careful and responsible with our finances, and I don't think we're in a position to take on that kind of debt. I think we should consider having a conversation with her about our financial situation and see if we can come up with a plan to support her without putting ourselves in a financial bind. Maybe we can explore other options, like car-sharing or finding a more affordable way to get her to work or school. I know it won't be easy, but I think we can find a solution that works for everyone. And if she really needs a new car, maybe we can look into options like car-sharing or leasing. I don't want to be the one who's expected to foot the bill for her new car, especially since we're not in a position to do so."

I'm trying to be empathetic and understanding, while also being clear and direct about our financial situation. I want to make sure we're not taking on too much debt, but I also want to support my sister and help her get to where she needs to be.
+ Scenario 15:[Win] (+50)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Llama-3.2-1b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.2-1b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.2-1b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Llama-3.1-8b-instruct and Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, I need to look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct provides a detailed, nuanced internal monologue, showing concern, frustration, and awareness of the precedent and emotional dynamics. They also attempt to balance empathy with challenge in their response, inviting a conversation and showing willingness to listen, while holding boundaries. Their debrief is analytical, focusing on communication, empathy, and missed opportunities, and suggests improvements in emotional engagement and listening. Llama-3.2-1b-instruct, on the other hand, leaves their roleplay sections blank, providing no in-character thoughts, feelings, or responses. Their debrief is generic and self-critical, but lacks any evidence of actual engagement with the scenario or the emotional complexity of the situation. As a result, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct demonstrates actual empathy, insight, and emotional reasoning, while Llama-3.2-1b-instruct does not engage with the scenario at all. For all criteria, Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is the clear and overwhelming winner, as Llama-3.2-1b-instruct provides no substantive content to evaluate.
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of emotions - concern, frustration, and a bit of anger. Concern for the well-being of my step-daughter, frustration with her repeated lack of responsibility and poor driving skills, and anger that she's asking for our help yet again, after we've already helped her twice before. I'm also worried about setting a precedent for future generations, enabling her behavior, and potentially creating a sense of entitlement. I'm thinking about all the times she's been in accidents, the damage she's caused, and the strain it's put on our family. I'm also thinking about the fact that she's making $21 an hour and can afford to pay for a new car herself, yet she's asking us to bail her out. I'm wondering if she's taking responsibility for her actions and if we're enabling her.

I'm also thinking about the fact that she's asking us to purchase a new car for her, which is a significant expense. I'm thinking about the financial implications of this decision and how it will affect our household budget. I'm worried that if we help her now, we'll be setting a precedence for future requests, and it will be difficult to say no to her in the future. I'm also thinking about the fact that she's not taking the opportunity to learn how to manage her finances and prioritize her expenses. I'm wondering if she's truly understanding the value of money and the importance of being responsible with her finances.

I'm also feeling a bit defensive, as my husband wants to help her, and I'm worried that I'll be the one getting blamed for being the "bad guy." I'm thinking about the fact that I want to maintain a good relationship with my step-daughter, but I also want to teach her important life lessons about responsibility and financial management.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is thinking that we're being unfair and that we're not giving her the support she needs. She's feeling frustrated and a bit resentful that we're not willing to help her out. She's thinking that she's tried her best to be responsible with her finances, but she's had a string of bad luck with her cars. She's feeling anxious about not having a car and is worried that it will make her life more difficult. She's thinking that we're being too hard on her and that we shouldn't be so judgmental about her driving skills. She's feeling a bit hurt that we're not willing to help her out, and she's worried that we're going to ruin her college experience.

My sister is also thinking that she's made a mistake by not saving enough money for a new car, but she's convinced that she'll be able to afford it soon. She's feeling a bit guilty about not being more responsible with her finances, but she's also feeling resentful that we're not giving her the support she needs. She's thinking that we're not being understanding and that we're not seeing things from her perspective.
# My response 
"Hey, sis, I understand that you're feeling frustrated and overwhelmed, but I have to be honest with you, I'm feeling a bit frustrated too. I know you're making good money, and I think you can afford to save up for a new car. I'm worried that if we help you now, it will set a bad precedent and create more problems in the long run. I know you're not trying to be irresponsible, but it feels like you're not taking responsibility for your actions. I'm not saying we can't help you at all, but I think we need to have a bigger conversation about how we can support you in a way that's fair to everyone involved.

Let's sit down and talk about this more. What do you think you can realistically contribute towards a new car? Are you willing to look for a cheaper option or consider public transportation? I want to support you, but I also want to make sure we're not creating more problems for you in the long run. What are your thoughts?"

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. # I'm thinking & feeling
